loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria M. is from the village of Dadda in Tuguegarao City. She is 58 years old. Maria is married and has nine grown children. To make a living, Maria owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock with her husband. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Maria has been engaged in her business for over 5 years, and she earns approximately 4500 PHP a month for these activities.

Maria joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maria has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. Maria is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Maria from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: María Olinda

texts.es: María Olinda M. de 49 años de edad, reside en el municipio de Ilopango, lugar en el cual vive junto a su grupo familiar el cual esta conformado por: su esposo el cual trabaja para una empresa privada, y junto a sus dos hijos. María tiene como profesión el ser costurera, ella se encarga de confeccionar ropa formal, uniformes y ropa casual, ella es alguien muy detallista quien desarrolla un trabajo muy bueno, lo que le permite contar con la fidelidad de muchos clientes como familiares, amigos y vecinos, ya que la responsabilidad es una de las mejorar cualidades de ella. María elabora trabajos por encargo y así mismo elabora prendas de vestir para vender en su casa de habitación, donde también se dedica a elaborar su trabajo. María solicita un préstamo con el fin de poder comprar telas en diferentes colores y estampados, así mismo comprar hilo, agujas y todo lo necesario para elaborar la ropa, María posee la certeza que de esta manera su negocio podrá mejorar y así obtener mayores ganancias las cuales sean de beneficio para su hogar.
texts.en:
María Olinda M., age 49, lives in the Ilopango municipality. She lives with her family, which is comprised of her husband and their two children. Her husband works for a private company. María is a seamstress. She makes formal clothes, uniforms, and casual clothes. She is quite meticulous, and she does very good work. This allows her to have many loyal customers like her relatives, friends, and neighbors. One of her best qualities is being responsible. María works by orders. She also makes clothes to sell in her house, which is where she makes the clothes. María is requesting a loan to be able to buy fabric in different colors and patterns. She will also buy thread, needles, and everything that is needed to make clothes. María is sure that this way her business will be able to improve. Then she will get greater income, which will be beneficial for her household.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fabric, thread, and buttons

loans.name: Tessie

texts.en:
Tessie R. is from the village of Centro Sur, Alcala, Cagayan. She is 58 years old, married and has 2 adult-aged children. Tessie owns and operates a general store, selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. Tessie has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2010, Tessie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Tessie is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Tessie from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Cristita

texts.en:
Cristita R. is from the village of Lantungan, Aurora, Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 41 years old, single and has 1 school-aged child. Cristita owns and operates a farming business, planting and harvesting  a variety of vegetables such as "kamunggay" and "kangkong" for sale. Cristita is just starting this business and has already earned 2,500 PHP.

In 2008, Cristita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cristita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC, which was used to to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. Cristita is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Cristita from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

Soledad is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 6th loan taken out by Soledad from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Carmen Elena

texts.es: Carmen Elena F. D. S. 45 años D. edad, es una señora muy alegre y amable, quien trabaja desD. su casa la cual esta ubicada en el departamento D. San Salvador. Ella posee una tienda en la cual venD. productos D. primera necesidad para el hogar y para las personas tales como: jabón, shampoo, pan, leche, golosinas, y otros productos más los cuales son básicos en este tipo D. negocios. Carmen vive junto a su esposo el cual trabaja como comerciante y junto a sus tres hijos quienes se dedican a estudiar en la universidad. Ella cuenta con muy buenas referencias por parte D. sus vecinos y amigos, ya que tanto Carmen como su esposo son dos personas muy trabajadoras, las cuales se dedican por completo al bienestar D. su hogar. Carmen solicita un préstamo a través del cual pueda surtir su negocio con todo lo necesario para aumentar su inventario y D. esta manera ofrecer más productos a sus clientes y así mejorar sus ganancias y poder salir adelante junto a su familia.
texts.en:
Carmen is 45 years old and a very happy and kind woman who works from her home, located in the department of San Salvador. She has a store in which she sells products of primary necessity for the home and for people, including soap, shampoo, bread, milk, sweets, and other products normally found in this type of store. Carmen lives with her husband who also works as a merchant, and their 3 children who study in the university. She can count on very good references from her neighbors and friends, since both Carmen and her husband are very hard-working people who dedicate themselves to the well-being of their home. Carmen requests a loan to restock her store with necessities and increase her inventory. In this manner, she will offer more products to her customers, improve her earnings, and be able to get ahead together with her family.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: BUYING PERISHABLE PRODUCTS TO SELL IN HER STORE

loans.name: Reina Isabel

texts.es: Reina Isabel L. O. de 31 años de edad, reside en el municipio de San Martín, ubicado en el departamento de San Salvador, lugar en el cual posee una tortillería la cual se encuentra en su casa de habitación, en donde vive junto a sus dos hijos de 10 y 4 años de edad, los cuales se dedican a estudiar educación básica y junto a su madre de 70 años de edad. Reina se dedica a la elaboración y venta de tortillas, las cuales comercializa de lunes a domingo tanto al mediodía como por las tardes, su madre le ayuda a hacer el trabaja más eficiente, ya que ella cuenta con varios clientes, los cuales se saturan, sobre todo en las horas pico. Este ha sido un negocio de mucha ayuda tanto para Reina como para toda su familia, por lo que solicita un préstamo a través del cual pueda comprar mayor cantidad de maíz, de esta misma forma comprar tambos de gas propano para poder contar con un pequeño almacenamiento de este, ya que en ocasiones durante el año el gas escasea lo que es muy perjudicial para su negocio. Reina es una mujer muy trabajadora, la cual se esfuerza al máximo por su familia.
texts.en:
Reina Isabel L. O. is 31 years old and lives in the municipality of San Martín, located in the department of San Salvador. This is where she has a tortilla shop which is located in her house. She lives with her two children, who are ages 10 and 4 and who study at the elementary school, and her mother who is 70 years old. Reina works making and selling tortillas, which she sells Monday through Sunday, more around midday than in the afternoons. Her mother helps her so she is able to work more efficiently in order for her to be able to help the many customers who fill her business, especially during peak hours. This business has been a great help for Reina and her whole family. She is requesting this loan in order to buy a larger quantity of corn and, also, to buy cans of propane gas to be able to keep some in storage for occasions during the year when gas is running short which can be detrimental for her business. Reina is a very hardworking woman especially when it is for her family.

Translated from Spanish by Alison Fanning, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy corn to make tortillas.

loans.name: Edna

texts.en:
Edna B. is from the village of Calamagui 1st. She is 55 years old, married and has 5 adult-aged children. Edna owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. Edna has been engaged in her business for over 30 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2007, Edna joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.es: Yolanda M. R. de 74 años de edad, reside en el Barrio San Carlos, ubicado en el departamento de La Unión, este barrio se encuentra a las orillas del mar, y es en donde Yolanda aprendió su oficio el cual se ha ido heredando por generaciones en su familia. Cuando era joven ella se dedicaba a la pesca artesanal, en la actualidad ella les brinda trabajo a otras personas, las cuales utilizan sus lanchas para salir a pescar, mariscos los cuales posteriormente Yolanda sale a vender al mercado regional de La Unión. Yolanda es una señora muy trabajadora quien se esfuerza a diario por contar con el sustento diario para ella y así mismo para el mantenimiento de su casa, debido a que ella vive sola y que no recibe ningún tipo de ayuda, solicita un préstamo a Integral, con el deseo de poder contar con el dinero necesario para invertir en la lanchas, y de este modo hacerle algunas reparaciones, y así mismo poder comprar mayor cantidad de combustible para ponerlas a trabajar y de esta forma realizar un trabajo más eficiente el cual le permita comercializa mayor cantidad de mariscos.
texts.en:
Yolanda M. R. is 74 years old. She lives in the San Carlos neighborhood, which is located in the La Unión department. This neighborhood is found on the banks of the sea. That is where Yolanda learned her craft, which has been inherited for generations in her family. When she was young she fished on a small-scale. Now she provides work for other people. They use her boats to go fishing. Yolanda later sells the seafood at the regional market in La Unión. Yolanda is a very hard-working woman. She puts forth daily effort to support herself and maintain her house. Because she lives alone, she does not have any type of help. She is requesting a loan from Integral. She wants to be able to have the money needed to invest in the boats. She will make some repairs, and she will be able to buy a greater quantity of fuel to be able to put the boats to work. This is the way to work more efficiently. It will allow her to sell more seafood.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fuel for the boats

loans.name: Mrs. Than Sothavy Seng Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan includes 15 villagers in Damnak village, Takeo province. Mrs. Than Sothavy S. is the village bank president. She is 38 years old and was selected by the other members who will use their portion of the loan in various ways to support their businesses in the current year. She is a pig breeder. Her husband, Mr. Trai Sen, is a taxi driver who owns a car in which he can earn some moN. to support his famiL.. Her problem is that her pigs are too small to sell, but she does not have moN. to support those pigs. So to improve this condition, Mrs. Than Sothavy S. is seeking a loan to buy pig food. She is a mother of three children, two of whom are enrolled in local school. The third child is just three years old.

loans.use: To buy pig food

loans.name: Rosa Amelia

texts.es: Rosa Amelia J. D. F. D. 41 años D. edad, resiD. en el departamento D. Usulután, y se destaca por ser una persona con grandes ganas D. salir adelante y esforzarse mucho para poder lograrlo. Ella vive junto a su esposo y así mismo tiene dos hijos, los cuales viven con la madre D. Rosa. Como toda mujer responsable y trabajadora, Rosa se dedica a comercializar ropa para mujeres, hombres y niños, la cual venD. D. forma ambulante por algunas D. las calles más comerciales y populosas D. Usulután, a pesar que cuenta con poca variedad D. ropa, ella posee varios clientes, razón por la que solicita un préstamo por medio del cual pueda comprar más variedad y cantidad D. ropa en diferentes tallas y colores. D. esta forma ella desea mejorar su negocio y así aumentar las ventas generadas por este todo con el fin D. contar con una vida mejor.
texts.en:
Rosa Amelia J. D. F., 41 years old, lives in the district of Usulután. She stands out as being a person with a great desire to do well, who makes a considerable effort to be able to achieve this. She lives with her husband and has two children who live with Rosa's mother. As a responsible and hard-working woman, Rosa sells clothing for women, men, and children, which she markets walking through some of the busiest, most populous commercial streets of Usulután. Despite having little variety of clothing, she has several customers. For this reason, she is requesting a loan with which she would be able to purchase more variety and quantity of clothing in different sizes and colours. In this fashion, she wishes to improve her business and also augment the sales this would generate, with the goal of having a better life.

Translated from Spanish by Heidi Petersen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase a variety of clothing.

loans.name: Hay Dee

texts.en:
Hay Dee P. is from the village of Calamagui 1st, Ilagan. She is 36 years old, married and has 3 school-aged children. Hay Dee owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. Hay Dee has been engaged in her business for over 14 years and earns approximately 12,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2007, Hay Dee joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Hay Dee has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI, which was used to purchase additional products to sell. Hay Dee is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 5th loan taken out by Hay Dee from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Roxana Elizabeth

texts.es: Roxana Elizabeth A. D. V. D. 31 años D. edad, resiD. en el municipio D. San Martín, lugar en el cual vive junto a sus dos hijos D. 15 y 13 años D. edad, los cuales  se dedican a estudiar gracias al enorme esfuerzo D. su madre, ya que ella es madre soltera quien siempre ha tenido que esforzarse por salir adelante y D. esta forma brindarles todo lo necesario a sus hijos. Roxana comercializa huevos en su casa, y así mismo los comercializa por mayor tanto en San Martín como también el pueblo D. Suchitoto, el cual esta ubicado en el departamento D. Cuscatlán, ahí ella se encarga D. abastecer a clientes los cuales cuentan con tiendas grandes y pequeñas. Roxana solicita un préstamo por medio del cual pueda comprar huevos por mayor, y D. esta forma obtenerlos más baratos y así mismo hacer crecer su negocio ofreciendo más producto. Ella es una persona muy responsable quien su prioridad mayor es la D. darles todo lo necesario a sus hijos y que estos no carezcan D. lo más básico y necesario para vivir.
texts.en:
Roxana Elizabeth A. D. V., 31 years old, lives in the municipality of San Martín. She lives with her two children, 15 and 13 years old, who attend school, thanks to the enormous strength of their mother, as she is a single mother who has always had to struggle to do well and in this way to proviD. all the necessities to her children. Roxana sells eggs in her home, and in this way she markets wholesale in both San Martín and in the village of Suchitoto, which is located in the district of Cuscatlán. There she is responsible for supplying customers who have both large and small shops. Roxana is asking for a loan by means of which she would be able to purchase eggs wholesale, and in this way obtain them more cheaply and also grow her business, offering more product. She is a very responsible person whose biggest priority is to give her children everything they need, that they don't lack the basic necessities for life.

Translated from Spanish by Heidi Petersen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of wholesale eggs for marketing.

loans.name: Florenda

texts.en:
Being born in a town where farming is one of the most common livelihoods, Florenda and her husband have been farming since they were young. Both their parents were also farmers and that was their main source of income. Florenda inherited a rice field from her parents; however; she didn't have enough capital to maximize the land for rice production or any agricultural business. In 2008, Florenda decided to join Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI) and get a loan to finance her farming business. 

Eventually, after Florenda's second loan from ASHI, she was able to accumulate some savings and make their farming business grow. Her 4 children who live with her and her husband have been very supportive. This loan is intended to finance her farming business. It is supported and agreed upon by her family, who promised each other that they would all help Florenda repay her weekly installment to ASHI on time.

Florenda's long term goal is to have a rice production business someday so that she can give the opportunity of employment to others, especially to her extended relatives in their barangay (village). Florenda hopes to maintain a long term sustainable farming business.

loans.use: To finance her farming business

loans.name: Ma. Eliz

Eliz owns & operates a general store selling a variety of different products like shampoo, toothpaste and more in the local community. Ma. loans.name: Reyna Matilde

texts.es: Reyna Matilde B. de 59 años de edad, reside en el municipio de Soyapango, ubicado en el departamento de San Salvador, lugar en el cual vive junto a su nieta de 13 años de edad, la cual estudia y se encuentra en total cuidado de Reyna y así mismo vive junto a una empleada la cual le ayuda con todos los oficios del hogar y la panadería. La señora Reyna posee una panadería, en la cual se dedica a trabajar desde hace 12 años atrás, es por esta razón que ella es muy conocida en la zona ya que siempre ha sido una mujer muy trabajadora la cual entrega todos los pedidos a tiempo y que cuenta con muy buenos estándares de calidad. En muchas ocasiones su nieta le ayuda a repartir el pan por los diferentes lugares en donde posee clientes fijos. Reyna solicita un préstamo a través del cual pueda comprar harina, manteca, miel, azúcar y otros ingredientes más, los cuales son necesarios para la elaboración del pan. Reyna trabaja arduamente día con día para poder brindarle todo lo mejor a su nieta, y así también poder mejorar el negocio, el cual ha sido muy rentable para ella.
texts.en:
Reyna Matilde B. is 59 years old, and lives in the municipality of Soyapango, located in the department of San Salvador. She lives with her 13-year-old granddaughter, who is in school and for whom Reyna is solely responsible. She also lives with an employee, who helps her daily with housework and the bakery. Reyna owns a bakery, where she has been working for 12 years. Thus, she is well known in the area, since she has always been a hard-working woman who delivers orders on time and who maintains a high quality standard. Her granddaughter often helps her distribute the bread to the various places where she has regular customers. Reyna is asking for a loan to buy flour, shortening, honey, sugar, and other ingredients needed for bread-making. Reyna works very hard each day in order to provide the best she can to her granddaughter, and thus improve her business, which has been highly profitable.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Jane Wilkie, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy raw materials for bread-making

loans.name: Marina Del Carmen

texts.es: Marina del Carmen U. A. de 48 años de edad,  reside en el Barrio San Jacinto, ubicado en la capital del país. Vive junto a su esposo, un señor muy trabajador, y junto a una hija y un hijo ambos de 18 años de edad, los cuales se dedican a estudiar. Marina posee su propio negocio en el cual comercializa flores, su puesto está ubicado desde hace 14 años atrás en el mercado de San Jacinto, en donde es muy conocida y buscada por las persona, ya que Marina no solo vende flores de excelente calidad, sino también elabora lindos arreglos florales para toda ocasión como bodas y bautizos. Gracias a este negocio ella ha podido contar con una vida mejor, es por esta razón que solicita un préstamo con el deseo de invertir aún más en su venta, comprando mayor cantidad de flores en diferentes estilos, así mismo comprar canastas, listones, tarjetas y toda la materia prima necesaria para realizar los arreglos floreales, lo que más espera Marina es poder atender mayor cantidad de personas y de esta forma poder percibir mayor cantidad de ganancias.
texts.en:
Marina del Carmen U. A. is 48 years old and lives in the San Jacinto Neighborhood, located in the capital. She lives with her husband, a hard-working man, and a daughter and son, both 18 years old, who are in school. Marina has her own business marketing flowers, and for 14 years has had a stand in the San Jacinto market. She is well known there and in demand, since Marina not only sells flowers of high quality, but makes floral arrangements for special occasions, such as weddings and baptisms. Her business has allowed her to enjoy a better life, and for this reason she requests a loan to invest even more in sales, buying larger quantities of flowers of different types, as well as baskets, ribbons, cards, and all the materials needed for floral arrangements. What Marina would like most is to serve more people and thus increase her earnings.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Jane Wilkie, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy flowers and materials for making floral arrangements

location.town: San Jacinto , departamento de San Salvador

loans.name: Nurgul's Group

texts.en:
Nurgul T. is the leader of her group. She is 48 and married. She has a 14-year-old daughter who is at school. Nurgul is a teacher of history at school and her husband works as a private driver. He earns 9,000 soms per month.  Nurgul and her husband breed livestock; they have been in this activity for 28 years.  Nurgul applied for the loan because she needs money to pay for her daughter’s education at school. In the future, she wants to improve her living conditions and give her daughter a good education.

Cholpon K., 33, is a widow. She has a three-year-old daughter. Cholpon works as a teacher of Russian language and literature at school. Cholpon hopes to obtain the loan because she needs money to pay her bills.
 
Chinarkul T. is the treasurer of the group. She is 40 and divorced. She has a daughter and a son. The son is a student and the daughter is pre-school age (under 7).  Chinarkul works as a teacher of Kyrgyz language at school. With money received from the loan, she wants to improve her living conditions and purchase a fridge. In the future, she wants to give her children a good education.

Syrga O., 34, is married. She works as a librarian and her monthly salary is 3,000 soms.  Her husband works as a private driver and receives 6,000 soms per month.  Syrga and her husband breed livestock. They have about 45 sheep. And now Syrga wants to start her own business. She plans to sell clothes at the market. With money received from the loan, she wants to purchase a variety of men’s and women’s clothes to resell them at a higher price at the market. In the future, she wants to expand her new business and make an effort to open a store. 

Rahat A., 48, is divorced. She has a 19-year old daughter who is a student. Rahat works as a teacher at school and her salary is not very high, so she is not able to pay for her daughter’s education at university. She hopes to obtain the loan to pay for her daughter’s education. In the future, she wants to see her daughter get married. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To pay for her daughter's education

loans.name: Mrs. Sok Keo Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. S. K. is a village bank president who was born in 1962. She has been selected president by the 16 people who make up a village bank loan located in Damnak village, TaK. province. All the members will use their portion of their loan for different purposes to improve their lives. 

Mrs. S. K. and her husband, Mr. Rort Thorn, are farmers who own a 3-hectare plot of land in which to cultivate rice to sell to support their family. Her problem is that her crop field has infertile soil and she does not have enough money to support it. So to improve production, Mrs. S. K. is applying for a loan to buy fertilizer and, with the rest of the loan, she will hire a plowing machine to plow her field and farming laborers to help her to grow rice. She is the mother of a child who is enrolled in school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Nazia's Group

texts.en: Nazia lives in a small city in Pakistan called Vehari. She is 26-year-old lady who married M. A. when she was a teenager. She lives in a three-room brick house with her family.  She is the mother of one son and a daughter. Both of them have not yet started going to school. She makes a decorative ornament called Paranda (an ornament to tie back hairs), which is used by woman and is famous among them as well. Her husband is a private entrepreneur who deals with scrap. He started this business two years ago and it is going well. He buys old & rotted items such as wooden & iron cupboards, bookracks etc and sells on good profit.  Nazia has applied for a loan from Asasah to financially assist her husband who wants to buy scrap for his scrap shop. Nazia is confident that her husband will be able to make positive changes to his business with this investment. This is her second loan and she a very responsible borrower. She used the prior loan ito start her husband’s scrap business.

loans.use: To purchase scrap

loans.name: Chhan

texts.en: Chhan C. earns a living by raising pigs in a pigpen behind her house. She raises them both for their offspring and for slaughter. In addition, she also assists her husband in the cultivation of crops from her own farmland. The couple married years ago but they don't have any children yet. Chhan C. will use the loan she has requested to buy more piglets for her stall. She intends to use any remaining money from the loan to use towards planting a rice crop.

loans.use: To buy more piglets for her stall.

loans.name: Tynymkan's Group

texts.en:
Tynymkan M. is the leader of her group. She is 64 and a widow. Tynymkan has been breeding livestock for 15 years, since 1995, and now she has seven sheep, a calf and two cows.  Tynymkan applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase feed for the livestock for the winter season. 

Aigul J. is the treasurer of the group. She is 38 and married. She has three daughters and a son who are at school. Two years ago, Aigul’s husband signed a contract with a company to provide transportation services. Aigul hopes to obtain the loan, because after having sold their old truck they don’t have enough money to purchase a new one. 

Kuluya M., 63, is a widow.  Her son works as a taxi driver and Kuluya takes care of his children. With money received from the loan, Kuluya wants to purchase auto parts to repair her son’s vehicle.  In the future, she wants to save some money and invite all the relatives to celebrate her 65th birthday.

Ainagul B., 39, is married. She has three daughters and a son. The son and the first daughter are in school. The other children are preschool age (under 7).  Ainagul is engaged in livestock and her husband makes money by providing welder services. Ainagul started to breed livestock five years ago with an initial investment of 13,000 soms. And now she has 14 farm animals. With money received from the loan, she wants to purchase two sheep to increase the number of livestock. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase feed for livestock

loans.name: Salamat's Group

texts.en:
Salamat lives in a city called Vehari with her husband and five children. Vehari is a small city located in Punjab province in Pakistan. Due to limited financial resources, her two sons couldn’t get an education and remain illiterate. They started working so their three sisters could get an education. Her eldest son is a daily wage laborer and the younger son has a business selling construction supplies. He lives in Lahore for his business. 

Salamat herself is a working woman. She sells embroidered clothes that she makes by herself. She purchases the clothes from Faisalabad and Multan and then embroiders them and sells them at her city’s local market at higher rates to earn a profit. 

Her husband is involved in a fruit-selling business. He sells fruit on his four-wheeled cart by visiting different areas of the city. Salamat has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband. With the loan, he will buy seasonal fruits in bulk to resell. She is hopeful that by increasing her husband's income, Salamat’s family can enjoy the basic necessities of life. This is her second loan and is a responsible borrower.

loans.use: To purchase seasonal fruits

loans.name: Mrs. Sivorn Yong Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan includes 15 people who live in Prey Mul village, Takeo province. Mrs. Sivorn Y. is the village bank president. She was born in 1980 and selected by the other members who will use their portion of the loan for different purposes to improve their businesses in this current year. She and her husband, Mr. Chhieng Lorn Hout, are farmers who own a two-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support their family. They also grow mushrooms and her husband is also a fisherman. Her problem is that her field has infertile soil and it is time to plow. So to improve rice production, Mrs. Sivorn Y. is seeking a loan to buy fertilizer and hire a plow machine to plow her field. She is a mother of four children. One of  the children is enrolled in the local school and the others are too small to work or study.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and hire a machine to plow

loans.name: Clarita

texts.en: Clarita is an old but strong mother who aims to become successful someday by developing her hog raising business. Clarita is thankful to ASHI. Through the loans they have provided since 2008, Clarita was able to support the maintenance of her hog raising business by purchasing the supplies she needed. She hopes to further improve the pig farm in the future through hard work and the continuous assistance of ASHI and Kiva Partner. Because of the lack of business capital, she was encouraged to seek financial support from KIVA lenders. She will be glad when her loan request is granted and she utilizes the loan wisely by purchasing the needed supplies for hogs. Her hard work and patience are her foundation in achieving to better their life. Her long-term goal is to have a pig farm someday. Clarita hopes to maintain a long-term sustainable hog raising business.

loans.use: To purchase supplies for her hog raising business.

loans.name: Aisuluu's Group

texts.en:
Aisuluu S. K. is the leader of this group. She is a 36-year-old widow.  She has three sons, all of whom are at school.  Nine years ago with the initial investment of 2,000 Kyrgyzstan soms Aisuluu started to sell convenience goods.  She now makes 13,000 soms per month; her profits made it possible for her to build a kiosk near her house. With this loan she wants to purchase a variety of convenience goods to increase the turnover of her business. 

Aida S. K. is twenty years old. She is engaged in cattle breeding. She started this activity two years ago with the initial investment of 2,000 soms. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase a bull, fatten it, and then resell it at a higher price. In the future she wants to increase the number of cattle she owns and finish the construction of her house.

Jamilya S., 45, is divorced. She has a daughter and a son; her daughter is married and lives separately with her family, and her son works in Russia.  Three years ago with the initial investment of 6,000 soms Jamilya started to breed livestock. Selling some sheep after fattening she makes 2,000 soms per month. With this loan she wants to purchase sheep for breeding.  In the future she wants to save some money to contribute to her son’s wedding.

Shyrman S. is the treasurer of the group.  She is a 44-year-old widow.  She has raised two sons and a daughter; the first son is married and lives separately with his family, the second son is at school, and the daughter works as a teacher in a kindergarten. Four years ago with the initial investment of 3,000 soms Shyrman started to sell convenience goods. In this way she makes 9,000 soms per month. She hopes to obtain this loan because she needs money to purchase a variety of convenience goods in order to increase the turnover of her business. In the future Shyrman plans to expand her business and build her own shop.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan.

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. 

To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase a variety of convenience goods

loans.name: Muzamil

texts.en:
Muzamil is a 29-year-old man with one child aged 4 years. He has no other dependents and his family is made up of three people. His family goal is to educate his child and open up a business for his wife. He owns his home located in Hoima, Uganda.

Muzamil has a salon business and has been in it for five years. He started as a barber in a friend’s salon and later on saved to start his own salon. He faces a challenge of load sharing of electricity and high rent. He hopes in future to turn his business into a big salon.

Muzamil wants the loan to pay the outstanding balance on his plot on which he intends to construct a commercial building.

loans.use: To pay the outstanding balance on land for construction of a commercial building

loans.name: Wycliffe

texts.en:
Wycliffe is a 36-year-old married man with three children. He lives in a semi-permanent house in the district of Kyenjojo, Uganda.

Wycliffe is a hardworking man who runs a maize mill. He dreams of improving his maize mill business by buying more machines.

Wycliffe wants a loan to purchase Irish potato seeds for planting.

loans.use: To buy Irish potato seeds for planting

loans.name: Adeela's Group

texts.en:
Adeela lives in the mid-sized city called Vehari in Punjab, Pakistan. She lives in a 4-room brick house in a village adjacent to the city. She is the mother of two sons, both of whom are illiterate and work for the Municipal Corporation. Her husband is doing a private job for low wages. 

Adeela supports her family financially by selling clothing. She purchases it from Multan and sells it to her local market for a profit. She has been in this business for the last two years and is getting good earnings from it.

She has applied for a loan from Asasah for her clothing sales business. With the loan, she will buy clothing in bulk. The bulk purchasing will minimize the cost of her traveling and increases her profits. 

She is in her second loan cycle and has been found to be a responsible loan user of Asasah. In her first year of loaning experience, she has maintained good credit behavior and never missed any meetings.

loans.use: Purchase clothing for reselling

loans.name: Aida

texts.en: Aida S. is from the village of Baclay, Tukuran, Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 61 years old, married and has 5 adult children. To make a living, Aida owns and operates a specialized retail store selling boost food, "longganisa", and "chorizo" (pork sausages) in the local community. Aida is just starting this business and already earned 4,000 PHP. In 2008, Aida joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Aida has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Aida is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Aida from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Wilson

texts.en:
Wilson wants a loan to enable him to buy a car for his transport business. He is a 35-year-old man who is married with three children.

Wilson started with a motorcycle transport business from which he saved money to buy a car for the business. With the loan, he will be able to have another car for his transport business.

Wilson lives in Kyenjojo, Uganda and owns the house in which he lives. He dreams of acquiring more land to build a commercial building.

loans.use: To buy another car for his transport business

loans.name: Rahima's Group

texts.en: Rahima A. is the leader of the group. She is 57, married and has a son and two daughters. Her son is working and the daughters are at school. Rahima is a teacher at school and her husband works as a taxi driver. A year ago Rahima got a loan in the amount of 10,000 soms and started to breed livestock. Now she applied for a loan because she needs money to purchase sheep in order to increase the number of livestock. Gulnur A. is the treasurer of the group. She is 41, married and has two daughters and two sons. Her first son and first daughter are at school, and the other children are preschool age (under 7 years). Gulnur is a teacher at school and her husband works in construction. A year ago Gulnur got a loan in amount of 10,000 soms and started to breed cattle. Having sold a bull after fattening she made 12,000 soms. Now with money received from this loan, she wants to purchase a cow in order to increase the number of cattle. Alymkan B., 41, is married and has three daughters and two sons. Her first daughter works in a casino, her first son works as a security guard, her second son is at school and the other children are preschool age. A year ago Alymkan took a loan and purchased five sheep for breeding. She applied for another loan because she wants to purchase sheep to increase the number of livestock. Galina R. is a 63 year old widow and she works as a teacher at school. A year ago she got a loan and purchased a bull for breeding. She sold that bull after fattening and made a profit of 8,000 soms. Now she hopes to obtain a loan to purchase cattle for breeding. ====================================== --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase sheep

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn H. is from the village of Lantungan, Aurora, Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 44 years old, married, and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, she plants and harvests a variety of vegetables such as "kalamongay" (leaves from the kalamungay tree make a healthy tea), "sayote" (a cucurbit like watermelon or cucumber), "squash" and more for sale. Jocelyn has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately $125 a month for these activities.

In 2008, Jocelyn joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. Jocelyn is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be her 3rd loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca J. is from the village of San J., Quirino. She is 60 years old, married, and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, she plants and harvests a variety of vegetables to sell. She has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately $350 per harvest for these activities.

In 2008, Rebecca joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. 

Rebecca is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. This will be her 6th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise

loans.name: Filmen

texts.en:
Filmen L. is from the village of Nacional, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. He is 35 years old, married, and has two school-aged children. To make a living, he provides hairdressing and beauty services to local community members. He has been engaged in his business for over seven years and earns approximately $180 a month for these activities.

In 2010, Filmen joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide his service. This will be his 1st loan from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve his business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase materials needed to provide his services

loans.name: William

texts.en:
William, aged 40 years, is a married father of seven children aged between 18 and 4. He lives in Kyenjojo, Uganda.

William runs a butchery which he started eighteen years ago. He wants a loan to buy more cattle for his butchery business. He dreams of doing butchery on a large scale for greater income generation.

loans.use: To buy more cattle for his business

loans.name: Perez

texts.en:
Perez A. J. is a widowed lady with four children between the ages of 21 and 12. 

Her business is located at the Jubilee municipal market in Kisumu. She sells fruits and vegetables to the local people and visitors as well. She has been in this business for ten years now and has one employee. She says that this business is profitable and the major challenge she has is there are so many people doing the same kind of business as hers in the area and so customers are spoiled for choice. She works very hard to keep her business doing well. 

Apart from the grocery business Perez gets more income from her rental houses. However, she is using her loan of  60,000 KES to buy more fruits and vegetables to expand her business and satisfy her customers' needs. She hopes to give her children a good education and add to the number of her rental units to increase her income in the future. She describes herself as kind, humble and God-fearing.

loans.use: to buy more fruits and vegetables to sell

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
Yolanda H. is from the village of Santa Isabel Norte, Ilagan. She is 49 years old, married, and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, she raises pigs for fattening and sale. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately $300 a month for these activities.

In 2010, Yolanda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. 

Yolanda is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which again will be used to purchase baby livestock. This will be her 2nd loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future

loans.name: Joy

texts.en:
Joy L. is from the village of Santa Cruz, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 48 years old, married, and has four school-aged children. To make a living, She provides mechanical services in her "repair shop" to local community members. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately $790 a month for these activities.

In 2008, Joy joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 40,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. 

Joy is requesting a new loan of 40,000 PHP which again will be used to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. This will be her 4th loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

He is just starting this business and already earned $100.

In 2008, Renato joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to repair an existing engine. 

Renato is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase tires and other accessories. This will be his 2nd loan from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family.

loans.name: Gulnaz

texts.en:
Gulnaz I. is a resident of Tashkomur, a small city in the Jalalabad region in the south of Kyrgyzstan.  Gulnaz is nineteen years old.  Ten years ago her mother opened a cafeteria and now Gulnaz works with her mom. She earns about $430 per month. That profit made it possible for her to invest money to start building a house.  

Gulnaz applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase sheep. After fattening, those sheep will be used for meat to prepare as food in their cafeteria. In the future she plans to expand their family business and maybe try to open a good restaurant. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase sheep

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith C. is from the village of Solinog Calamba Misamis Occidental. She is 41 years old. Judith is married and has two school-aged children. Judith owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste,C2 drinks, Nescafe, coffee mate, and diapers in the local community. Judith has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 15,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it.

In 2009, Judith joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid her last loan from GDMPC, which was for 35,000 PHP and was used to purchase additional inventory & as working capital.

Judith is now requesting her second loan from GDMPC, for 50,000 PHP, which will be used to to expand the business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

About GDMPC:

loans.name: Gorreti

texts.en:
Gorreti wants a loan to buy more tapes to sell and passion fruits for making juice for her business. She is a 39-year-old lady who is married with six children and lives in the small township of Kyenjojo, Uganda.

Gorreti dreams of starting a wholesale shop which sells every domestic item and she says she can achieve this feat through hard work and commitment.

loans.use: To buy more tapes to sell and passion fruits for making juice to sell

loans.name: Razia's Group

texts.en:
Razia belongs to a small city of south Punjab Pakistan called Vehari. She lives in a three room brick house with her husband and three sons. Her eldest son is studying in 6th standard, the next to him reads in 6th standard also, while the youngest one reads in kindergarten. 

Razia couldn't complete her own education due to the limited financial resources of her family but she wants to provide all the possible resources to her sons for getting a quality education. She is a very hard-working lady. She operates a grocery shop at her house. She has occupied a room of her house where she keeps the groceries and meets the requirements of her customers. She started doing this work a few years ago to financially support her husband. It is going well now. 

She also handles another business of selling clothes. She takes it as a part time business to supplement her income. She sells those clothes which she imports from Faisalabad and Multan. 

She has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband who has been involved in the animal selling business for the past ten years.  With the loan amount, he will buy goats which he will sell on Eid (a muslim holiday which comes after Ramadan) for a good profit. 

Razia is confident that her husband will be able to earn a good profit on this Eid and that that will help her family to improve its living condition. 
Note: "In this photo, Razia is showing her selling-clothes business".

loans.use: Purchasing goats for animal selling business

loans.name: George

texts.en:
George would like a loan to buy better breeds of cattle for his livestock business. He is 65 years old and is married with eleven children.

With pension money, George started his livestock marketing and hardware business after he had retired from formal employment with the civil service. He lives in Kyenjojo, Uganda and owns the house in which he lives.

George dreams of acquiring a milk-processing plant which he says can be very profitable, given the fact that there is no other local milk processor in his area.

loans.use: To buy better breeds of cattle for his livestock business

loans.name: Risa Oleku

texts.en:
Risa is 27 years old, he practices livestock farming in Naivasha.  He buys, rears, and later sells the animals at a profit during the peak season. 

He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his first loan.  He plans to buy ten goats and five sheep which he will sell later at a profit.

Risa hopes to have his own farm on which he can rear his animals and to be a major supplier of meat in Naivasha town.

loans.use: buying goats and sheep

loans.name: Antonio

texts.en:
Antonio O. is from the village of Puntod Lopez Jaena Misamis Occidental. He is 59 years old. Antonio is married and has four adult children. Antonio owns and operates a retail business. The main source of income for the business comes from selling rice in the local community. Antonio has been engaged in his business for over 15 years and earns approximately 1,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it.

In 2008, Antonio joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to do business. Antonio has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from GDMPC. He is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase more rice to sell. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Antonio from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the daily needs of his family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

loans.name: Andricus

texts.en:
Andricus O. A. is a married man but has no children yet. His business is located at Kisumu Bus Park Market, an area in Kisumu which is very busy. He sells phone accessories. He also does phone charging services and phone repair. He has been in this business for six years now and has one employee. He says that this business is profitable and the major challenge he has is financial constraints on getting a bigger premises with adequate space. However he works very hard to keep his business doing well. 

He is using his loan of 80,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) to buy more phone accessories to provide good service to his customers. He hopes to grow his business in the next five years and become a big phone shop. He also has a dream to alleviate poverty through educating youths informally to engage in business activities. He describes himself as interactive, social and self motivated.

loans.use: Phone Accessories

loans.name: Jackline

For over six years she has been in the business of selling groceries, women lessos and charcoal.  Jackine is now requesting her second loan from KADET to purchase vegetables, lessos, and one sack of charcoal for her store. With the profits she hopes to assist her husband in paying for the children's school fees.  Jackine aspires to become a great and very successful business lady.

loans.use: To purchase vegetables, lessos and one sack of charcoal for her grocery store

loans.name: Gorrett

Gorrett is a young lady, 31 years old, and is a single mother of three children between 13 and 2 years old. She has no other dependents apart from her children and her family therefore consists of four people. She owns her home and her family goal is to educate her children.

Gorrett lives in Hoima, Uganda where she has operated a bar business for five years. She started as a housemaid then later on worked as a bar attendant before saving some money which she used to start her own small bar. The only challenge she has is that electrify bills are always too high. In future she would like her business to grow into a big pub.

Gorrett wants the loan to furnish her chicken house with a good floor and to buy more chicks.

loans.name: Banin

texts.en: Mr. Banin H. and his wife, Mrs. Sokea Chhom, have been married since 1995 and have two sons who are in school. Banin obtained a previous Kiva loan and he wants to continue increasing his productivity. texts.en:

His wife is a vegetable vendor and they have five children aged between 2 and 12 years. They hope to give their children good education to the university level. 

Amos says that this business is profitable, and that the major challenge he faces is having a permanent place to do business. He is using his loan of Kes 40,000 to buy sacks of charcoal to grow his business and meet customer demands. He hopes to build a new house for his family since the house he owned was demolished by the municipal council. In the future, he dreams of diversifying to real estate business. He describes himself as being humble, god-fearing and social.

loans.name: Bashiran's Group

texts.en:
Bashiran is a homemaker who also works part-time selling blankets. She has a four-room house in a mid-sized city of Pakistan called Vehari. She has a 16-year-old daughter studying in eight grade, and who is keen to become a doctor. Bashiran is striving hard to fulfill her daughter's dream by trying to provide her quality education.  Her blankets selling business helps her to bear her daughter's education expenses. 

Her husband works as a supervisor in a private company for a reasonable income. She has applied for a loan from Asasah to expand her business. With the loan amount, she plans to buy blankets in bulk and work full-time on this business. She is a very active and enthusiastic lady. She is confident that she will be able to expand her business and improve her financial condition by investing money in her business. She is in her fifth loan cycle and has found to be a responsible loan user of Asasah.

loans.name: Valentina

texts.en:
Valentina is married and has two grown up children. She sells women's clothing at a small market in the Zaporozhye city. Valentina has been in this business for 10 years. 

Valentina has a competitive advantage: when new clothing arrives at the wholesale market, Valentina receives a call from the wholesale apparel managers from whom she buys her inventory, and she gets her new assortment earlier than her competitors. This is because Valentina maintains a good relationship with the wholesale managers and always pays them on time.

Valentina enjoys selling women's clothing and would like to develop her business further. She is requesting a loan of 10,000 UAH to increase the assortment of fall clothing.

Like most of the people living in his area, Steven deals in produce majorly selling maize which he buys from farmers and sells at a profit to bigger consumers in urban areas. 

Like any other business person, Steven has a dream of opening more stores for his maize-selling business. He wants a loan to buy maize  for resale.
