Ligaya has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 6,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Ligaya joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ligaya is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Ligaya from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Matilda

texts.en:
Matilda R. is a 37 year old single mother and a boutique proprietor in Kikambala Mombasa dealing with  women hand bags and cloths. She supports her two children and has been in the business for the past three years. This, being her second loan with KADET micro-finance, Matilda is looking forward to purchasing more stock of handbags and clothes for her business. She will use the anticipated profit to build her mother a house and to carry out repairs in her boutique.

In future she hopes to access more loans from KADET to boost her income.

loans.use: To purchase more stock of handbags and clothes.

loans.name: Alam's Group

texts.en:
Alam lives in the small city of Vehari, Pakistan. She has a 3-roomed house and lives in it with her family. She has a daughter who is 17 years old and studies in 10th standard. Her husband is working in the government sector, but his income alone is not enough to fulfill the basic needs of the family. This is why Alam also works to share the financial burden of the family. She operates a blanket-selling business. She has been doing this work for over 10 years.  

Alam’s business is now established and she has maintained a good customer base from different cities such as Lahore, Faisalabad and Islamabad. Now she receives a good number of orders. To fulfill those orders on time he has to have the blankets in large quantities, otherwise it will negatively affect her business. Therefore, she has applied for a loan from Asasah. With the loan amount she will buy blankets in larger quantities, which will minimize her cost and improve her chances of making more income. 

Alam’s only daughter, named Madiha, has a dream to get higher education. For that purpose, Alam works very hard to provide her with all the facilities of a good & quality education. Alam is in her 2nd loan cycle. She fulfilled her responsibilities as a loan user very well last year and paid all the installments on time.

loans.use: Purchase blankets for reselling.

loans.name: Alvin

texts.en:
Alvin R. is from the village of Sta. Isabel Norte, Ilagan, Isabela. He is 22 years old. Alvin is single. To make a living, Alvin owns & operates a business raising crops, primarily planting and harvesting rice for sale. Alvin has been engaged in his business for over 3 years and earns approximately 45,000 PHP per harvest for these activities.

In 2010, Alvin joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. Alvin is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Alvin from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure.

loans.name: Leonida

texts.en:
Leonida D. R. is from the town of Rizal West, San Isidro. She is 49 years old. Leonida is married and has 1 grown child. To make a living, Leonida owns & operates a business selling home products primarily ingredients such as onions and vegetables. Leonida has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Leonida joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Leonida has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Leonida is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 10th loan taken out by Leonida from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand the business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en:
Rosalinda N. is from Barangay Tuao North, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 58 years old, married and has 6 adult children. To make a living, Rosalinda owns & operates a business selling fruits & vegetables in the local community. Rosalinda has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 6,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Rosalinda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Rosalinda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Rosalinda is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Rosalinda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering.

loans.name: Sianto

texts.en:
Sianto L., 34 years old, and her husband, Samson, have four children. They have been rearing and selling animals in Naivasha town for the last nine years.

Sianto was introduced to KADET by her friend. This will be her first loan. She plans to use the cash to buy more goats which she will sell in December when it's peak season.

Sianto is also planning to start crop farming in the future on her piece of land.

loans.use: To buy more goats to sell in December.

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en: Emmanuel wants a loan to buy a fridge for his business. He is 45 years old, married with three children. He has a retail shop which he has run for a year. He lives in Kyenjojo, Uganda. He owns a permanent house in which he lives. Like most people in his locality, Emmanuel also nurses a dream of acquiring a maize mill to process the huge maize harvest produced in the area.

loans.use: Buying a  fridge for cooling drinks for his business

loans.name: Mrs. Sampheas Yav Village Bank Group

texts.en: The 14 people included in this village bank loan are villagers in Prey Mul village, Takeo province. Mrs. Sampheas Y. is the village bank president. She is 22 years old and was selected by the other members who will use their portion of the loan for different purposes. She and her husband, Mr. Some Mut, are farmers who own a one-hectare plot of land where they can grow rice to sell to support their family. She also grows mushrooms and her husband owns a plow machine. Her problem is that her field has infertile soil, but she does not have enough money to support the field. So to improve production, Mrs. Sampheas Y. is requesting a loan to buy fertilizer. With these activities, they support a child who is two months old.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Ambrose

texts.en:
Ambrose K. is a 33-year-old timber dealer, landlord, and milk supplier in Majengo Kanamai Road next to Mwembera hardware, Mombasa.

He is married to Martha Muskyoka who is a teacher. They have three children.

Ambrose is requesting his second loan from KADET to expand his timber yard and to build a shed for the timber.

In the future he hopes that his business will grow and thus improve the living standard for his family.

loans.use: To expand his timber yard and build a timber shed.

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou G. is from the village of Centro Sur, Alcala, Cagayan. She is 47 years old and married with 4 school-aged children. 

To make a living, Marilou raises pigs for fattening and sale. She has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Marilou joined ASKI to improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting her first loan of 5,000 PHP which she will use to purchase additional feeds for her hogs. She plans to use the additional revenue to financially support her family.

About ASKI


ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers,  fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.


Note

To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional feeds for her hogs

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria A. is from the village of Calamagui 1st. She is 42 years old and married with 3 school-aged children.

To make a living, Gloria runs a general store where she sells a variety of different products in the local community. Gloria has been engaged in her business for over 9 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Gloria joined ASKI to improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gloria successfully repaid a previous loan of 10000 PHP from ASKI which she used to purchase additional products to sell.

She is requesting her 8th loan, for 17000 PHP, which she will be use to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to financially support her family.

About ASKI

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

Note

To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Mary Grace

texts.en:
Mary Grace is 30 years old, married, and lives in the province of Antique in the Philippines with her husband and four young children (ages 3 to 8). To supply additional income for her family, Mary Grace is opening a prepared food stall (ready-to-eat) in her neighborhood.

Mary Grace would like to receive a loan to purchase inventory of ingredients for her business. Mary Grace believes in offering a varied menu in her stall for customers seeking convenient purchases. A new member of Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), a Kiva microfinance partner in the Philippines, Mary Grace is grateful for the access to capital and loans to fund her entrepreneurial dreams.

Her long term goals are to expand her business, fund the college education of her children, and support her family financially. With the support of ASHI and Kiva lenders, she is determined to achieve business success with her new entrepreneurial endeavor.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients

loans.name: Prima

texts.en:
Prima G. is from the village of Sta. Isabel Norte, Ilagan. She is 30 years old and married with 4 school-aged children.

To make a living, Prima raises pigs for fattening and sale. Prima has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Prima joined ASKI to improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She successfully repaid a previous loan of 4000 PHP from ASKI which she used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future.

Prima is requesting her second loan from ASKI, for 6000 PHP, which she will use to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support her family.

About ASKI

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

Note

To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise and sell.

loans.name: Hellesy Seveni

texts.en:
Hellesy Naise is 49 years old.  He is from the town of Sigalagala in Kakamega. He is married to Phanince Cheptoo and they have one child, Sharon Libese, who is 10 years old and in primary school.

Hellesy has been running a secretarial bureau where he makes photocopies and sells stationery. He is applying for his first loan from us after being introduced to KADET LTD by a friend who is a client here. He intends to use the money to buy photocopy paper and another photocopier since the one he is using is old and is not serving him well. His business is situated near the Sigalagala Institute and this means that he has a huge clientele from there.

His dream is to become a very stable businessman and venture into the printing business in the future.

loans.use: Buy another photocopier

loans.name: Mrs. Kung Yav Village Bank Group

texts.en: The Prey Mul village in the Takeo province has ten people who have been selected and who all make up a village bank loA..  All the members will use their portion of the loA. in varied ways to support their businesses in this current year.  Mrs. Kung Y. is a village bank president who was born in 1944.  Mrs. Kung Y. and her husband, Mr. Chhoeun A., are farmers who own a one-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support their family.  Her problem is that her field has infertile soil, but she did not have enough money to support it.  So to improve her production, Mrs. Kung Y. is applying for a loA. to buy fertilizer. With the rest of the loA., she will rent a plow machine to plow her own field.  The couple has a child who is a laborer.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and a plow.

loans.name: Zakhir

texts.ru:
Zakhir G. 33 let. On jenat i imeyet odnoqo sina kotoromu 6 let on v etom qodu poydet v shkolu. Zakhir i eqo semya jivut v Fuzuli regione. 

Zakit uje 5 let kak rabotayet taksistom. Vodit mashinu eqo nauchil eo otec . Zakir ochen lubil vodit mashini i on ochen akkuratno vodil i poetomu reshil stat taksistom. Zakir Seychas nujdayetssya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit zapchasti dlya toqo chtobi pochinit mashinu.
texts.en:
Zakhir G. is thirty-three and married with one six-year-old son, who will be going to school this year. He and his family live in the Fuzuli region. For five years Zakhir has worked as a taxi driver. He learned how to drive from his father. He loved driving and was good at it so he decided to become a taxi driver. Zakhir currently needs 2000 AZN to buy spare parts so he can fix up his car.

Translated from Russian by Jill Heske, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy spare parts.

loans.name: Khut

texts.en: Mrs. Khut N., age 38, is married with four children, all of whom are working. She is a domestic pig breeder who owns a medium pigpen. In addition, Khut N. weaves thatch to sell to raise extra money. She has another financial earner in her husband who owns a horse-cart that he uses to pick up firewood from the forest to sell at their house. Khut N. requests a loan to repair her house. (Mrs. Khut N.'s husband is pictured.)

loans.use: To repair her house.

loans.name: Prossy

texts.en:
Prossy N. is 17 years old and lives in the town of Natete in the Kampala West region of Uganda.  She is single and has one child, who is not yet in school.  Prossy runs a hotel, which she has had for less than one year.         

To help expand her business, Prossy has requested a loan of 150,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more stocks of food, such as rice and beans, for the hotel's use.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Prossy hopes to generate greater profits and sometimes buy food.  In the future, Prossy hopes to go back to school. Prossy is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by learning how to play new games and sharing experience. 


Note to lenders: BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva which funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program.  This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan. The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills.  Afterward, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses.  These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age and improve their prospects for the future, and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance.  Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans, and give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.use: To buy more food for her hotel

loans.name: Judith

texts.en: Judith A. is a forty-two-year-old food kiosk owner and greengrocer in Kwa charo wa maes Market in Kilifi.  She is married to Michael Olweny, who supports her income. They have four children, two of whom are independent.  Judith A. has been in her business for one year and is now borrowing her second loan from KADET. She plans to add more cereal and vegetables to her grocery and also purchase stocks of flour and rice.  She will use part of the loan to invest in a saloon business. She will use her anticipated profit to expand her food kiosk business and see her saloon business grow in the future.

loans.use: To add more cereal and vegetables to her grocery and also purchase stocks of flour and rice.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To increase working capital

loans.name: Minda

texts.en:
Minda C. is from the village of San Pablo Proper, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 46 years-old and married with three adult children. To make a living, Minda owns and operates a business raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income comes from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Minda has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP when she sells her raised animal.

In 2010, Minda joined Kiva partner ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Minda is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and then sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Minda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishers and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock.

location.town: San Pablo Proper, Cauayan City, Isabela

loans.name: Daken

texts.en:
Daken H. is 54 years-old and lives with his wife and two children in Bayan-Ulgiy province of western Mongolia in a ger -- a traditional nomadic housing tent. His elder son helps with his business and his daughter attends a local middle school.  His wife is a handicapped and stays at home. 

Daken operates a taxi service between the countryside and the capital of the province. He started his business in 2000 with a big van transporting people to Kosh Agash - a border point with Russia. After ten years in business, his car has been getting quite old, therefore Daken transports people only twice a week now. He works very hard to provide for his family. He is a polite and creative person who wishes to buy a newer and small car so he can earn more. [Daken is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to import a variety of clothing for personal use.]

loans.use: To buy some clothes by his car.

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan N. is 18 years-old and lives in the town of Natete in the Kampala West region of Uganda.  She is unmarred and has no children. For the last year, Susan has had a hotel (small restaurant) business.         

To help expand her business, Susan has requested a loan of 150,000 Ugandan Shillings from Kiva partner BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase and stock food like rice for use at the hotel.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Susan hopes to generate greater profits and sometimes pay school fees.  In the future, Susan hopes to go back to school. Susan is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by increasing her business.

Note to lenders:

BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva which funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program.  This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan. Initially, the ELA program provides disadvantaged adolescents, particularly girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills.  Later, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses.  These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age, improve their prospects for the future, and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance.  Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans, give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.use: To buy food and supplies such as rice.

loans.name: Mrs. But Chan Village Bank Group

texts.en: Mrs. But C. is the village bank president. She is 53 years old. She was selected by the 14 members who will use their portion of the loan for different purposes. They are all located in Prey Mul village, Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice to support her family. She is a widow with six children. One of the children is a translator, one is a seamstress in a garment factory, and the others attend school and help do the farming. Her problE. is that her children's work place is far away from her home. So to solve this problE., Mrs. But C. is asking for a loan to buy a new motorcycle for her children's transportation.

loans.use: To buy a new motorcycle

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam N. is 21 years-old and lives in the town of Natete in the Kampala West region of Uganda.  She is married and has two children.  None of her children are currently in school.  For the last three years, Mariam has had a beauty salon business.         

To help expand her business, Mariam has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from Kiva partner BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more hair dryers.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Mariam hopes to generate greater profits and sometimes buy food.  In the future, Mariam hopes to own a shop of cosmetics. Mariam is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by getting more knowledge on how to live her life through reading story books at the club and learning how to dance and sing. 


Note to lenders:

BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva which funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program.  This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan. Initially, the ELA program provides disadvantaged adolescents, particularly girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills.  Later, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses.  These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age, improve their prospects for the future, and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance.  Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans, give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.use: To buy more hair dryers.

loans.name: Peris

texts.en:
Peris M. is 27 years-old.  She is a resident of Shingila and a Tailor in Kilifi town kwa Karanja.

Peris is married to Karisa Kashindo who supports her and they have two children aged four and eight years respectively.

She has been in business for the last ten years and is now requesting her second loan from Kiva partner KADET.

She plans to increase her stock of cloth materials for her shop and then use the anticipated profit to buy a new sewing machine for her business.

In the future, Peris would like her business to provide an employment opportunity for someone and to succeed in life.

loans.use: To purchase materials.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth M., a 21-year-old resident of the town of Natete in the Kampala West region of Uganda, is single and has two children, both in school. Elizabeth has a beauty salon that she has operated for nine years.

To help expand her business, Elizabeth has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda to purchase more dryers. With the help of the loan, she hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees. In the future, Elizabeth hopes to own a training school for catering, tailoring and hair dressing. Elizabeth is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future.

Note to lenders: BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva which funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan. The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills. Afterward, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses. These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age and improve their prospects for the future, and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance. Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans and give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.use: To buy more hair dryers

loans.name: Silveriana

texts.en:
Mrs. Silveriana C. is from the Barangay of Labuyo, Tangub City, Misamis Occidental. She is 49 years of age and a widow. She is blessed with four children, three of whom are now already adults and one is still a teenager.  To make a living, she is presently engaged in operating a mini carenderia and snack vending activity. She is also receiving regular support from her children in terms of some basic and immediate needs. She’s been engaged in this kind of service activity for 5 years already and earns approximately Php3,000.00 a month from this business activity.

In the year 2008, Silveriana joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Silveriana, as an active member of PMPC under the PDP-LP Program, a microfinance program that reaches out to rural communities, has successfully repaid a loan amount of Php5,000.00. She is requesting a loan amount of Php5,000.00 as her 7th loan availment to be used for an existing mini carenderia and snack vending business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family, especially in meeting their basic needs, saving for future use, loan repayments, her child’s education, insurance and possible business expansions. 
		
About PMPC:
 Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for her mini eatery and snack vending business

location.town: Labuyo, Tangub City, Misamis Occidental, Mindanao

loans.name: Amos

texts.en: Amos is a young, energetic man aged 26, married with three children, living in his own house in Kyenjojo, Uganda. As for his family, Amos wants his children to study up to the university level just like most Ugandans nowadays. Amos says he has been having a financing gap in his business and that's why he has opted for a loan to enable him to reach the next level in his business. He wants the loan to buy more maize, beans and coffee for resale.

loans.use: Purchasing maize, beans and coffee for resale

loans.name: Milagros' Group

texts.en:
Milagros A. is from the village of Bunawan, Calamba. She is 52 years old. Milagros is the group leader of a two-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Milagros is married and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, Milagros owns & operates a business selling pigs in the local community. Milagros has been engaged in her business for over 12 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Milagros joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Kulash began her consumer goods retailing business in 2004 and after a successful business operation she managed to start a billiards service out of the market in her town. A kind and creative woman planning to expand her business, she works hard every single day. Kulash is now requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more billiard tables for her business.

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam N. is 19 years old and lives in the town of Natete in the Kampala West region of Uganda.  She is single and has no children. Mariam has a business selling vegetables, which she has had for 2 years.         

To help expand her business, Mariam has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more vegetables.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Mariam hopes to generate greater profits and buy food.  In the future, Mariam hopes to go back to school. Mariam is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by helping her learn how not to be selfish with others. 


Note to lenders: 

BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva which funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program.  This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan. The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills.  Afterward, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses.  These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age and improve their prospects for the future, and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance.  Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans, and give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.use: to buy more vegetables

loans.name: Melodie

texts.en:
Melodie A. is 54 years old and married with two adult children.   She lives with her family in the province of Antique in the Philippines.  Her husband works as a farmer.  To supply additional income for her family, Melodie is starting a hog-fattening business.  She is ambitious and determined to launch a successful business venture of her own.

Melodie would like to receive a loan to purchase piglets and feed for piglets.  As a new member of Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), a Kiva microfinance partner in the Philippines, Melodie is thankful for access to capital in the form of loans to support her entrepreneurial dreams.   Her long-term goals are to build a sustainable business, fund her children’s college education, and to construct a more durable home that can withstand the flooding common in her town.

With the support of ASHI and Kiva, Melodie is hopeful that her new business will generate steady income to improve her financial stability and her family’s quality of life.

loans.use: To purchase additional piglets to raise

texts.en:
Batool Azra lives in a small city of Punjab, Pakistan, called Vehari. She is a 57-year-old lady who lives in a small house with her family. She has given birth to a daughter who is now married. She is also a grandmother of her daughter’s daughter, who is 13 years old and reads in 7th standard.  

Batool has spent her life serving her family. She is a housewife, staying at home and carrying out the responsibilities of a housewife and a mother very well.  

Her husband's name is J. and he has a business of selling water-filter sets. He purchases water filters from the electronics shop and sells them to the local markets of his native city. He has been doing this business for the last 15 years. 

Batool has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband. With the loan amount, he will buy the water-filter sets and sell them to different electronic shops. 

She is hopeful that this investment will help her husband to improve his business conditions and to earn more profit. This is the first time Batool has applied for a loan with any microfinance institution (MFI) and she wants to build a long-term relationship with Asasah.

It is time to plow her field, but she does not have enough moN. to do that, so she is asking for a loan to rent a plow for plowing her field. She is the mother of six children, one of whom is a seamstress in a garment factory, three are studying in the local school, and the others are too young to work or study.

loans.name: Phoeun's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Phoeun P., born 1967, leads a group of five members in Ta Koam Village, Takeo Province, Cambodia. She was selected as leader by the other members of the group who will use their portion of the loan for various ways to support their families. 

Mrs. P. is a successful pig breeder who supports her family with profits from the business. Since her breeding pig is going well, she would like to expand her operation. In order to do so, Mrs. Phoeun P. is seeking a loan to buy more piglets and pig food. 

Mrs. P.'s husband is a farmer who cultivates rice on a plot of land he owns to support the family. She is a mother of six children. One is a seamstress in garment factory, one is a construction worker, three are attending in school, and the youngest one is four years old.

loans.use: Purchase piglets and food for breeding

loans.name: Loy

texts.en:
Loy N. is 21 years old and lives in the town of Natete in the Kampala West region of Uganda. She is married and has 3 children. Two of her children are currently in school. Loy has been running a tailoring business for the past 2 years.          

To help expand her business, Loy has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more materials like cloth for sewing. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Loy hopes to generate greater profits and sometimes buy food. In the future, she hopes to own a tailoring school. She is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by helping her to become a good leader and learning how to be confident. 

Note to lenders: BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva which funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan. The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills. Afterwards, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses. These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age and improve their prospects for the future, and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance.  Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans, and give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.use: to buy sewing materials

loans.name: Ruyonza 2 Tukore, Ibanda Group

texts.en:
A. Fednand has been overseeing his bar business in Ruyonza, Ibanda for 6 years, using savings from his agricultural enterprises. In the bar, he sells soft drinks like sodas, beers, wines and gins, alongside banana sales. Since his business got on a firm footing, he has been able to make the most out of it.
 
In one month, this focused, married father of 3 children makes 280,000 Ugandan shillings profit. With this money he has managed to cater for his children’s education and his family's general welfare. He has come to grips with some inevitable business challenges; he has however not lost heart. The determination he carries in himself means he is full of optimism that the future of his business will be bright. On that basis, he has come to terms with the fact that he needs a loan to be able to revamp his business with more stock purchases.

loans.use: to purchase more stock of beers, sodas and wines

loans.name: Felix Liyayi

texts.en:
Felix L. is 37 years old from Shinyalu in Kakamega. He is married and has two children; Philip L. who is 18 years old and Josephine who is 15 years old.

Felix is a carpenter and has been doing this business for the past 13 years. He is applying for his first loan from us having been introduced to Kadet Ltd by a friend who is also a client. He intends to use the money to buy more timber to add to his business. His business is located along the road to Kakamega road.

His hope and dream is to open another carpentry business in Kakamega town.

loans.use: to buy timber

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Thirty-eight year old Mary wants a loan to clear land for planting water melons and for paying labor. She has a banana plantation from which she earns income.

Mary is a married lady with four children. She lives in a permanent house in Kyenjojo, Uganda. She  dreams of having an educated family, several sources of income, and having a plantation of eucalyptus trees for additional income generation.

loans.use: To clear land for planting water melons and for paying labor

loans.name: Ernita

texts.en:
Mrs. Ernita T. is from the village of Sto. Niño, Tangub City, Misamis Occidental. She is 47 years of age, a widow, and is blessed with 4 children of whom two are now working and the other two are school-aged. To make a living, she is presently engaged in a banana buying and selling business. She’s been engaged in this kind of business for 20 years already and earns approximately Php 3,000 a month from this business activity. Aside from that she is also receivinging support from her daughters who are presently working in Lebanon in an amount of not less than Php 10,000.

Just this year, Ernita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. As a newly recognized member of PMPC under the Regular Loan Program, Ernita is now requesting a loan amount of Php 15,000 as her 1st loan to be used as additional capital for her  existing banana buying and selling business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her general living conditions,  especially in meeting her basic needs, saving for future use, loan repayments, insurance, and possible business expansion. 

About PMPC:

 Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for her banana buying and selling business

location.town: Sto. Niño, Tangub City, Misamis Occidental, Mindan

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary Nakanja is 21 years old and lives in the town of Natete in the Kampala West region of Uganda. She is married and has 3 children. All of her children are currently in school. Mary has a business selling matooke (green plaintain), which she has had for 2 years.         

To help expand her business, Mary has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more matooke.  With this loan from BRAC, Mary hopes to generate greater profits and to pay school fees. In the future, Mary hopes to own another business like charcoal sales. Mary is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by learning how to deal with customers through financial literacy training. 

Note to lenders: BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva which funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program.  This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan. The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills.  Afterward, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses.  These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age and improve their prospects for the future, and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance.  Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans, and give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.use: to buy more matooke

loans.name: Kousar's Group

texts.en:
Kousar lives in a three-roomed house in a city called Vehari which is located in Punjab, Pakistan. She is 39 years old, married to M. A. and has one daughter. She owns & operates a clothes sewing business. She sews clothes based on orders she receives from her neighborhood and from various boutiques.
 
Her husband is attached to a milk selling business. He sells milk in different areas of the city. He leaves home at 7am, taking milk on his motorbike in big jars to supply to different homes and shops. He has been doing this work for over five years. He has a buffalo which produces 8-12 kg milk for him which earns him almost 360-540 PKRs per day.
  
Kousar has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband who wants to enhance his business by purchasing another dairy cow. In this way he will be able to increase his milk production, which he can then supply to a good number of clients.
 
Kousar hopes that the loan will enable her husband to make a positive change in his business and increase his income. Kousar is a new loan user and she hopes it will be a good experience for her.

loans.use: to purchase another dairy cow

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia N. is 21 years old and lives in the town of Natete in the Kampala West region of Uganda. She is single and has one child who is currently not in school. Lydia has a business offering secretarial services such as printing. She has done this for 3 years.         

To help expand her business, Lydia has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more paper and ink for printing. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Lydia hopes to generate greater profits and to pay the school fees for her young sisters.  In the future, Lydia hopes to own a house. She is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by improving her business and increasing her profile. 

Note to lenders: BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva which funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program.  This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan. The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills.  Afterward, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses.  These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age and improve their prospects for the future, and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance.  Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans, and give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.use: to buy more ink and paper

loans.name: Mrs. Sinerth Khon Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan is made up of nineteen people who live in Ta Non village, Takeo province. Mrs. Sinerth K. is the village bank president, born in 1984 and selected by the other members who will each use portion of the loan for different purposes to improve their family's living conditions. She and her husband, Mr. Ret Ry, are farmers who own a very small piece of land to cultivate rice on to sell to support their family; moreover, Mrs. Sinerth K. is a weaver. Since her weaving is going well, she wants to expand. So to improve her current business, Mrs. Sinerth K. is asking for a loan to buy more silk. She is a mother of one child who is six years old.

loans.use: To buy more silk

loans.name: Ireme Tukwatanise, Ibanda Group

texts.en:
Hard working and cooperative 36 year-old married father of four children M. Junior, has been operating a goat selling business from I., Ibanda for over four years.  He started up with a small amount of capital from his still existing farming business. 

M. Junior buys goats from the surrounding villages which he slaughters and gets ready for selling to his genuine customers who have supported him this long.  His business has grown to the extent that he has been able to have his children go to school. In a month, Junior says that he makes 160,000 Ugandan shillings.  He also makes some additional income through his side agricultural business where he sells coffee and bananas. His drawback is having only a small stock of goats therefore he would like to use this loan to restock his business and buy more goats for grazing and fattening. His future plans are to expand his business and improve his sales revenue.

loans.use: To buy goats.

loans.name: Narcisa

texts.en:
Narcisa is 40 years-old and married with four children. Narcisa lives with her family in the province of Antique in the Philippines.  Her husband works long hours as a fisherman to support the family.  To supply additional income, Narcisa wants to start-up a fish selling business through securing working capital from lenders.
 
Narcisa would like to receive a loan of 4,000 PHP to purchase an inventory of fish.  With more fish to sell, Narcisa believes that sales will increase leading to higher revenue.

A new member of Kiva partner ASHI, she ensured strong performance with regular attendance in group meetings and steady repayments.  Narcisa is thankful for access to capital and loans to support her entrepreneurial dreams.  With the support of ASHI and Kiva, she is hopeful that her business will continue to flourish to improve the family’s quality of life and fund all of her children’s education until they finish college.

loans.use: To purchase fish to sell.

loans.name: Mrs. Koem Heng Ly Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Twelve people who live in Damnak village in Takeo province make up this village bank loan. All the members have selected Mrs. K. Heng L., born in 1961, as village bank president. They will all use their portion of their loan in varied ways to support  their families. 

Mrs. K. Heng L. and her husband, Mr. Saroeun N., are farmers who own one-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice on to sell to support their famiL.. Moreover Mrs. K. Heng L.  is also a pig breeder. Since her  pig breeding is going well, she wants to expand. So Mrs. K. Heng L. is applying for a loan to buy more piglets and pig feed. She is the mother of four children, one of whom is a translator, while another one is a seamstress in a garment factory, and the others are studying at school.

loans.use: To buy more piglets and pig feed

loans.name: Lourdes

texts.en:
Lourdes C. is from the village of Estrada, Quezon. She is 27 years-old and married with one school-aged child. To make a living, Lourdes owns and operates a food stall. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income comes from tending a canteen in the community. Lourdes is just starting her business.

In 2010, Lourdes joined Kiva partner ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lourdes is requesting a first loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishers and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Mary Rose

texts.en:
Mary Rose J. is from the village of Villa Concepcion, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 21 years-old and unmarried with a baby. To make a living, Mary Rose owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes  from selling fish in the local community. Mary Rose is just starting this business.

In 2010, Mary Rose joined Kiva partner ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mary Rose is requesting a first loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to supplement the family income. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishers and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Clarita

texts.en:
Clarita R. is from the village of Salay Angadanan, Isabela. She is 49 years-old and married with three school-aged children. To make a living, Clarita owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income comes from selling food and daily use products in the local community. Clarita has been engaged in her business for over 17 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Clarita joined Kiva partner ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Clarita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Clarita is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and to provide working capital. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Clarita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishers and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to provide working capital.

loans.name: Kitamba Turibamwe Group, Ibanda

texts.en:
Hard working and trustworthy 32-year-old married father of two children, M. Jackson is a professional teacher who does other side businesses such photography in his free time. He is further involved in agricultural farming where he carries out cattle fattening. 

He has been doing this for three years in Kitamba, Ibanda, and is able to earn about $67 on a monthly basis from the photography. His drawback is having a small stock of cows in his farming business. Therefore, he would like to use this loan to restock his cattle business by buying more cows for fattening and later resale for a profit. 

His future plans are to expand his business and improve his sales revenue. He wants to improve his family's living conditions and build a residential house.

loans.use: buying more cows for fattening and resale

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
Anita F. is from the town of Rizal West, San Isidro. She is 59 years old, married, and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, she sells vegetables. She has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately $100 a month for this activity.

In 2009, Anita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase materials needed to provide her service. 

Anita is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional materials needed to provide service. This will be her 3rd loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase materials needed to provide service

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en:
Rosalinda V. is 24 years old, married with two children, and lives in the province of Antique with her husband.  Her husband works as a laborer to support the family.  Her eldest child attends the local elementary school in the community and the youngest is a 10-month-old baby.

To supply additional income for her family, Rosalinda would like to receive a loan to start a new hog raising business.  With the loan, she will purchase piglets and feed for them. She will raise them for approximately four to six months until they are ready for resale.

A new member of Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), a Kiva micro-finance partner in the Philippines, Rosalinda is grateful for access to capital and other services such as savings and insurance.  With the support of ASHI and Kiva lenders, Rosalinda is hopeful that her new business endeavor will provide steady income and improvements in her family’s quality of life.

loans.use: To purchase piglets and feed

loans.name: Kigarama Women's, Ibanda Group

texts.en:
S. Mariat is a hard working and an ever optimistic 37-year-old married mother of five children between the ages of 20 and 10. 

She operates a thriving produce business in Kigarama Trading Centre, Ibanda, dealing in the buying and selling of cereals like millet, rice, sorghum, beans, peas and more. 

With a business longevity span of seven years, Mariat has managed to significantly sustain and improve on her family’s welfare status through paying the school fees for her children and providing for her family's general welfare. To all appearances, her future business prospects look rosy with close to $124 coming in monthly out of her business.  

She envisions an even greater profit margin as she gets this loan, anticipating being in a position to buy more stock for the business. This will enable her to expand her business, educate her children, develop her plot of land and also be able to earn more revenue and live a self-sustaining life.

loans.use: to purchase more stock for resale

loans.name: Mrs. Aun Nget Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan is made up of fifteen people who live in Pou village, Takeo province. All the members in this village will use their loan for varied purposes to improve their businesses. Mrs. Aun N. is the village bank president, born in 1976 and selected by the other members. She and her husband, Mr. Cham N., are farmers who own a plot of land to cultivate rice on to sell to support their family. Moreover he is a construction worker and he is also a fisherman. 

Mrs. Aun N.'s problem is that her rice field is far away from the irrigation system. So to improve her production, Mrs. Aun N. is asking for a loan to buy a pump. Any remainder of the loan will be used to buy rice seed. She is the mother of two children, one of whom is studying in school while the other is helping her to do farming.

loans.use: To buy a pump

loans.name: Salvacion

texts.en:
Salvacion N. is 40 years old and married with three children.  She lives with her family in the province of Antique in the Philippines. To supply additional income for her family, Salvacion is starting a business of hog fattening.  She is motivated and determined to launch a successful business endeavor of her own. Salvacion would like to receive a loan to purchase feed and vitamins for hogs. 

As a member of Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), a Kiva micro-finance partner in the Philippines, Salvacion is thankful for access to capital and loans to support her entrepreneurial dreams. Her long term goals are to build a sustainable business and fund her children’s education until they finish college.  With the support of Kiva lenders, Salvacion is positive that her business will generate sound profits to improve her financial stability and her family’s quality of living.

loans.use: To purchase feed and vitamins for hogs.

loans.name: Mrs. Mao Suon Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Sixteen people from Pou village, TaK. province, make up this village bank loan. Mrs. Mao S., 32, is the village bank president who was selected by the other members, each of whom will use their portion of the loan for different purposes. She and her husband, Mr. Chea Sou, are farmers who own a half-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice on to sell to support their family. She also owns a general store in the local village while her husband is a policeman. 

Since her business is going well, Mrs. Mao S. wants to expand. So  she  is applying for a loan to buy more groceries to resell. With the remainder of the loan, she will buy two piglets to raise to start a new business. She is the mother of three children, two of whom are attending school, while the youngest one is two years old.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to resell

loans.name: Aiganysh

texts.en:
Aiganysh D. is a resident of Tup, a nice town in the Isykul region with a population of 15,000 people. She is a 54-year-old widow. She has raised two daughters and four sons. The daughters are married and live separately with their families and the sons are working, except for the youngest son who studies at school. 

Aiganysh works as a teacher of physics at the school. She is also engaged in farming. In 1995 when the collective farms broke up, she got a parcel of land where she cultivates fruits and vegetables.  She also sells milk for making money. 

With the money received from the loan, Aiganysh wants to purchase 400 liters of fuel which is needed for the sowing process. In the future she wants to see her sons get married. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused micro-finance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only micro-finance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. 

To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase fuel for the planting season

loans.name: Rahat

texts.en:
Rahat A. is a resident of Tup, a nice town in the Isykul region with a population of 15,000 people. She is 52 years old and married. She has raised five daughters. The first daughter is married and lives separately with her family, the second studies at the university and the other daughters are at school.  

Rahat has been engaged in farming since 1995. She also breeds cattle. Rahat applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase 300 liters of fuel. In the future she wants to build a big house and give her children a good education.

loans.name: Nazgul

texts.en:
Nazgul M. is a resident of Tup, a nice town in the Isykul region with a population of 15,000 people. She is 42 years old and married. She has three sons and two daughters. The first son is a farmer, the first daughter studies at university, the second son is at school and the other children are of preschool age (under 7). 

In 1995 when the collective farms broke up, Nazgul was given a parcel of land, so since that moment Nazgul has been engaged in farming.  She hopes to obtain the loan because she needs money to purchase 300 liters of fuel for farming. In the future she wants to give her children a good education.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

loans.use: to purchase fuel

loans.name: Mrs. Sokha Prak Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan is made up of sixteen people who have selected Mrs. Sokha P., born in 1983, as village bank president. They will all use their portion of the loan for different purposes to improve their businesses in this current year. They are located in Kampong Luong village in Takeo province. 

Mrs. Sokha P. and her husband, Mr. Koeun Sok, are farmers who own a one-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice on to sell to support their family; he is also a fisherman. Mrs. Sokha P.'s problem is that her husband does not have a fishing boat to use. So to solve this problem, Mrs. Sokha P. is seeking a loan to buy a fishing boat. She is the mother of four children, two of whom are attending school, while the youngest two are five years old and one month old.

loans.use: To buy a fishing boat

loans.name: Mrs. Sophea Dong Village Bank Group

texts.en:
These twelve people make up a village bank loan in Kampong Luong village, Takeo province. They will each use their portion of the loan for different purposes to improve their businesses in this current year. Mrs. Sophea D., 41, is the village bank president selected by the other members. She is a farmer who owns a 1.5-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support her family and she is also a coffee seller in her local village. Since her coffee sales are going well, she wants to expand but she does not have enough money. So to improve her current business, Mrs. Sophea D. is seeking a loan to buy more coffee to resell. 

Her husband, Mr. Chim Thoung, is a healer. She is a mother of four children, one of whom is helping her to sell coffee, while another is a seamstress in a garment factory, and the others are attending school.

loans.use: To buy more coffee to sell

loans.name: Anastacia

texts.en:
Anastacia Q. is from the village of Cabisera 5, Ilagan, Isabela. She is 49 years old, married, and has six school-aged children. To make a living, she plants and harvests a variety of vegetables to sell. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately $63 a month for these activities.

In 2009, Anastacia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. 

Anastacia is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. This will be her 4th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise

loans.name: Luzviminda

texts.en:
Luzviminda L. is from the village of Cabisera 25. She is 44 years old, married, and has five adult-aged children. To make a living, she raises pigs for fattening and sale. She has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately $100 whenever she sells her raised animals.

In 2009, Luzviminda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. 

Luzviminda is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase more baby livestock. This will be her 3rd loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future

loans.name: Mr. Bol Va Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mr. Bol V., village bank president, born in 1980, comes from Thum village, Takeo province. The fifteen members of the village bank who elected him will each use their portion of the loan for different purposes to improve their current businesses.

Mr. Bol V. is a farmer who owns a half-hectare plot of land where he can grow rice to sell to support his family. His wife, Mrs. Phearum P., is a salesperson at the local market where she can earn a large profit to support her family. Mr. Bol V.'s problem is that his wife does not have a motorcycle to transport items for her business. So to improve this business, Mr. Bol V. is asking for a loan to buy a new motorcycle. He is the father of two children both of whom are too young to work or study. 

On the day of the loan disbursement, Mr. Bol V. was busy working in the field. Instead, his wife, Mrs. Phearum P., received the loan for him.  Mr. Bol V.'s wife is in the photo above.

loans.use: To buy a new motorcycle for  transportation of business goods

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary M. is a 34-year-old single mother who lives with her 4-year-old son in Jomvu, Mombasa. She earns her livelihood by hawking clothes (going door-to-door) in the area where she lives.

Mary currently wishes to expand her business so as to use the anticipated profit for her son’s education. The photo taken was during a KADET group meeting and this marks Mary's first loan from KADET. She intends to use the money to stock up her clothes business in the process of expanding it.

In the future, Mary hopes to become a successful business lady.

loans.use: To stock up her business in the process of expanding it

loans.name: Mrs. Thoeurn Prum Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Thoeurn P., village bank president and 58 years old, was selected by sixteen people who live in ThU. village in Takeo province. Each member will use their portion of the loan for different purposes to improve their current businesses. 

Mrs. Thoeurn P. and her husband, Mr. Chorn Nus, are farmers who own a small piece of land to cultivate rice on to sell to support their family. Although both of them try to work hard in their field, they can earn very little income to support their family. So to improve this condition, Mrs. Thoeurn P. is asking for a loan to buy some piglets to raise to start a new business. With any remainder of the loan she will buy a bicycle and fertilizer. She is the mother of four children, two of whom are seamstresses in a garment factory, while one is studying at the local school, and the other is helping her to do farming.

loans.use: To buy some piglets for breeding and possibly a bicycle and fertilizer

loans.name: John Mukhono

texts.en:
John L. is 45 years old and is married to Everline Mukhono who is 42 years old. They have four children: the first born is Fexil, 25 years old; then Agnes, 20 years old; Benson, 18 years old; and the last born is Ephaim, 16 years old. John and his family live in the Morongiot area of Vihiga. His wife owns a retail maize shop and the profits made are mostly used to support the family.

John is a carpenter and has been in this business for the past eleven years.His workshop is in Vihiga town and he currently has some orders from his clients that he needs to work on.

John needs money to purchase wood for his carpentry work and he is applying for his 3rd loan from KADET after successfully completing his second one. He intends to use the profit made, to expand his business and be comfortably able to pay his children’s school fees. 

John’s main hope is to establish a carpentry training workshop. He also has a desire to buy a piece of land that he will use to build a permanent home for his family.

loans.use: To purchase wood for his carpentry work

loans.name: Mrs. Yeng Hun Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan is made up of thirteen people who live in Chrouy village in Takeo province. All the members have selected Mrs. Yeng H. is the village bank president. She is 33 years old. They will each use their portion of the loan for different purposes which can improve their businesses. 

Mrs. Yeng H. owns a general store in the local village while her husband, Mr. Roeun San, is a farmer who owns a more than one-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice on to sell to support his family. He is also a laborer. 

Mrs. Yeng H.'s obstacle is that her husband’s field has a lot of insects, but she does not have enough money to help him. So to improve rice production, Mrs. Yeng H. is seeking a loan to buy pesticide and rice seed. With any remainder of the loan, she will hire a plow to plow her field. She is the mother of a child who is enrolled in school.

loans.use: To buy pesticide and rice seed

loans.name: Bayram

texts.ru:
Bayram S. 20 let. On ne jenat i jivet v Fuzuli regione vmesto so svoyey semyoy. Baymar imeyet 2 sestri kotoriye mladshe neqo.

Bayram uje 2 qoda kak rabotayet v kafe. Ranshe  Bayram  imel malenkuyu butku qde on qotovil " Tantuni" i prodoval tam je a teper on  rasshiril svoyo pomesheniye i reshil sdelat iz neqo kafe i poeotmu on Seychas nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit stoli i stulya dlya svoyeqo novoqo kafe.On xochet razvit svoy bizness.
texts.en:
Bayram S. is twenty-years-old. He is unmarried and lives in the Fuzuli region along with his family. He has two younger sisters. For two years Bayram has worked in a cafe. Previously he had a small kiosk where he made and sold "Tantuni" [sauteed beef wraps]. Now he's expanded his space and decided to make it into a cafe, so he needs a 2000 AZN to buy tables and chairs for his new place. He would like to grow his business.

Translated from Russian by Jill Heske, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy tables and chairs.

loans.name: Janylkan

texts.en: Janylkan A. is a resident of Tup, a nice town in Isykul region with a population of 15,000 people. She is a 52-year-old widow who has raised six sons and a daughter. Her three older sons are married and live separately with their families in Bishkek and the other children live with their mom. Janylkan started her own business in 1994 - at that time she was selling food in the market. Then she saved some money and started to sell clothes. When the children are free they help their mom with her activity. Janylkan hopes to obtain the loan because she needs money to purchase school uniforms in order to sell them in autumn, when the school season begins. Also, she will use a part of the loan to purchase convenience goods: five bags of sugar and five bags of macaroni in order to resell them at a higher price in the market. In the future, Janylkan wants to expand her business, improve her family’s living conditions and have enough money to support her children in the future. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.
