Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase school uniforms and convenience goods to sell

loans.name: Suiumkan

texts.en: Suiumkan A. is a resident of Tup, a nice town in Isykul region with a population of 15,000. She is a 54-year-old widow who has raised three daughters and a son: her son is married and lives separately with his family; two older daughters study at university; and the youngest daughter is at school. In 1995, because of the high unemployment rate, Suiumkan decided to start her own business and began to sell foodstuffs in the market. Then she saved some money and opened a butchery. With money received from this loan, Suiumkan wants to purchase eight sheep in order to sell the meat in her butcher shop. In the future she wants to expand her business, give her daughter a good education and have enough money to support her children in the future. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase eight sheep for her butcher shop

loans.name: Marichu

texts.en: Marichu F. is from the village of Rizal. She is 22 years old, married and has 2 infant children. To make a living, Marichu owns and operates a general store selling a variety of different products in the local community. Marichu has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month from these activities. In 2010, Marichu joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marichu is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Marichu from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. AAbout ASKI: ASKI is one of the pioneer microfinance institutions in the Philippines committed to serve the needy in Central and Northern Luzon through socio-economic development and holistic transformation. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Mr. Phal Neang Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mr. Phal N. is the village bank president; he was born in 1979 and was selected by eight village bank members located in Prey Thum village, Takeo province. Each member will use their portion of the loan in varied ways to support their current businesses. 

Mr. Phal N. and his wife, Mrs. Sey Oun Sam, are farmers who own a small piece of land to cultivate rice on to support their family. He is also a motorcycle and bicycle repairman while his wife is a farm laborer. His problem is that his field has infertile soil, but he does not have enough money to amend it. So to improve rice production, Mr. Phal N. is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer and rice seed. He is the father of two children who are both too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and rice seed

loans.name: Merlita

texts.en: Merlita P. is from the village of Rizal. She is 54 years old, married and has 6 adult children. To make a living, Merlita owns and operates a business raising pigs for fattening and sale. Merlita has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP when she sells her raised animal. In 2007, Merlita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Merlita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 16,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase breeding livestock. Merlita is requesting a new loan of 18,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be the 7th loan taken out by Merlita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the pioneer microfinance institutions in the Philippines committed to serve the needy in Central and Northern Luzon through socio-economic development and holistic transformation. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Patricidra

texts.en: Patricidra S. is from the village of Rizal. She is 58 years old, married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Patricidra owns and operates a business selling personal products from Avon and MSE in the local community. Patricidra has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from these activities. In 2008, Patricidra joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Patricidra has successfully repaid a previous loan of 18,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Patricidra is requesting a new loan of 18,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be the 6th loan taken out by Patricidra from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the pioneer microfinance institutions in the Philippines committed to serve the needy in Central and Northern Luzon through socio-economic development and holistic transformation. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Tukundane Bakyara, Ibanda Group

texts.en:
The hard work, as well as the social and creative nature of K. Flora, has seen her operate a thriving business of handling a bar business alongside growing bananas located in Ibanda town. The widowed mother of two children has been running these businesses for the last seven years and earns approximately $43.

Her current setback is having too little capital to purchase more stock, including beer and soft drinks, for the bar. This loan will help her to revive the business in terms of expansion, and she will also be able to earn more revenue to fulfill her family's requirements and to educate her fatherless children.

loans.use: stocking more beer and sodas in the bar

loans.name: Musa

texts.en:
Twenty-nine-year-old Musa is a married man with three children. He lives in a house in Kyenjojo, Uganda.

To earn income, Musa supplies power in Kyegegwa town using a generator and wants a loan to service his generator.

Musa dreams of building a permanent residential house and becoming the sole supplier of power with support from government.

loans.use: To service his generator

loans.name: Naranbat

texts.en:
Naranbat L. is 23 years old and lives with his wife and daughter in Hovd province, in western Mongolia. 

He began his secondhand clothing retail business with the help of his wife in 2009, after resigning from his job as a music teacher in a local kindergarten. Over the past two years, Naranbat and his wife have proven to be very hard-working entrepreneurs with both business and customer service experience. The couple hopes that when the time comes, he and his wife will be able to afford to improve their own lives. 

Naranbat is requesting a 1,200,000 MNT loan in order to purchase more clothing for his business and increase his working capital.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing

loans.name: Mairo Mbili Drivers Association Group 1-Jinja

texts.en:
She is an industrious lady who has been at the helm of a six-year-old beauty salon business in Jinja. Running a business like this requires making continuous audacious decisions and that is exactly what M. Regina has been doing. Her set objective has always been to see her business get into that position of improved circumstances. This diligent lady used the money she had set aside as savings to open this business. Her first business was a pub.

This 48-year-old single mother of four makes about $13 a week.  She supplements these profits with earnings from her charcoal-selling business. Customers at her beauty salon are mostly community members. With this loan, she wants to buy more hair chemicals and hair pieces for her salon and also more bags of charcoal for reselling.

loans.use: to purchase more hair chemicals for her beauty salon and bags of charcoal for reselling

loans.name: Mukwano  Development Group-Jinja

texts.en:
Eight years ago, after 27-year-old N. Suzan got some cash from her husband, she did not hesitate to bring her business plans into fruition. She, on the spur of the moment, began her beauty salon business in Jinja Town.  By all appearances, Suzan is a hard-working woman whose chances of future success are looking like being in the ascendant in the course of every passing day. This all boils down to the fact that she is a stickler for hard work and she plans for her business constantly. In a week, she gets about $22 as net profit. 

She has two children who are certain to bask in the glow of her continual success. She has, however, been hard pressed at buying new things like creams for her salon. It is for that reason that Suzan says this loan will come in handy in helping her buy more cosmetics, weavers, driers and other basic requisite equipment for her salon. She is positive that with more creams in her salon and with more equipment she will attract more clients. This, she says, will help her make much more profit than she is making now.

loans.use: The purchase of more cosmetics, weavers, driers and other equipment for her beauty salon

loans.name: Elvira's Group

texts.en:
Elvira M. is the leader of the group.  She is 48 and married. She has two sons. The first son studies at university and the second is at school.  Elvira works as a teacher of music,and she is also engaged in cattle breeding.  She started this activity two years ago with the initial investment of 5,000 KGS.  Now, selling some farm animals after fattening, she makes about $65 per month. Elvira applied for the loan because she needs money to pay for her son’s education at the university.  In the future she wants to increase the number of cattle and save money to start building a house for her son.

Kanatbek J., 49, is married. He has a 16-year-old daughter. In order to make money Kanatbek works as a taxi driver, and his wife is a teacher at the university.  Kanatbek is also engaged in cattle breeding. He started this activity ten years ago with the initial investment of 10,000 KGS and now, selling some farm animals after fattening, he makes about $108 per month.  With money received from the loan he wants to purchase hay for cattle to feed them during the winter season. 

Aida T., 35, is divorced. She has a 13-year-old daughter who is at school.  Aida works as a teacher of music, and she is also engaged in cattle breeding. Her brother helps her with this activity. Selling some cattle after fattening, she makes about $173 per month. Aida applied for the loan because she needs money to prepare her daughter for school; that is, to purchase a school uniform, paper goods and so on.

Asel B. is the treasurer of the group. She is 29 years old and married. She has a daughter and a son, both of whom are at school.  Asel is a teacher of music at school and her husband works as a security guard at a gas station. Four years ago, with the initial investment of 6,000 KGS, Asel and her husband started to breed cattle. Selling some animals after fattening they make aboiut $228 per month. That profit made it possible for them to save money and purchase a vehicle. Asel hopes to obtain this loan because she wants to improve her living conditions and purchase furniture for her home. In the future she plans to repair the house.

Indira K., 40, is married.  She has a daughter and two sons, all of whom are at school. In order to make money her husband works as a taxi driver. Indira owns some land where she cultivates apricots. When selling part of the harvest she makes about $195 per month. With money received from the loan Indira wants to purchase school uniforms for her children. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused micro-finance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only micro-finance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. 

To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to pay for her son's education at university

loans.name: Tilekberdi

texts.en:
Tilekberdi U. is 36 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Bayan-Ulgiy province in western Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His elder two children attend a local middle school and the youngest son stays at home with his mother. 

Tilekberdi operates a delivery business with his big truck and supplies local customers with coal. He began his business in 2000, and after several years of hard work and saving, he managed to buy his own big vehicle and expand his customer base.  He says, “I worked hard every day to purchase a heavy load truck for my business, which cost about 60,000,000 MNT, in order to improve my family’s quality of life.” 

Tilekberdi is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan for purchasing a trailer for his big truck in order to increase the load turnover and make deliveries to Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia.

loans.use: To purchase a trailer for his big truck

loans.name: Ggulu Development Group-Mukono

texts.en:
Any business gains a credible reputation when the owner is highly principled. Integrity is a vital attribute that should elevate the prospects of any business. A certain 30-year-old hard-working lady by the name of N. Sylivia lends credence to the above. Her good demeanor has over the last three years struck a good chord with clients who incessantly flock to her popular general retail shop in Ggulu-Mukono. Being honorable has also been another trump card that she has used to the advantage of her business. 

Her shop deals in an array of goods such as soap, sugar and beans. In a week her profit returns add up to about $45. Under the auspices of this loan, she wants to buy more bags of beans, rice, sugar and maize flour, all for resale.

loans.use: The purchase of more bags of beans, rice, maize flour and sugar.

loans.name: Kyegwisa Bakyara Twimukye, Ibanda Group

texts.en:
Hard-working K. Ovia has, over the last 16 years, been overseeing her growing spare parts business in Kyegwisa trading center in Ibanda. With a monthly net profit of $107, this married lady has enjoyed the good graces that have come with running this lucrative business.

Consequently, she has made enormous progress in educating her four children, which is a concern in the family. Her first priority after acquiring this loan is to purchase more hardware inventory with the sole objective of turning her business into a big supply store for motorcycle and bicycle spare parts. This will help her earn more sales revenue to take care of her family's needs.

Ovia belongs to a group of members who hold each other accountable and insure one another in paying back their loans.

loans.use: to buy more spare parts for motorcycles and bicycles

loans.name: Agali Awamu Kikajjo Group-Kampala

texts.en:
The long and short term odds for success in most new businesses are dependent on many factors, but for 26-year-old M. Erid those odds have been improved because of a wealth of confidence, good blueprint planning and lots of good will from close friends. These factors have helped her to break new ground in her six-year-old beauty salon business in Namasuba-Kampala. 

She has been unrelentingly hard-working over the course of these years, and her husband has also been at her beck and call. This has helped her a great deal. Erid and her husband have one child. Her customers range from old to young women who reside in Namasuba - a growing suburban area in its own right.  

Erid says she will be empowered by this loan to buy weavers and driers for her salon. She says this will be a springboard for making more profits for her business, as her workers will be able to expedite the work that they do.

loans.use: The purchase of weavers and driers for her salon

loans.name: Jumakul's Group

texts.en:
Jumakul A. is the leader of this group. She is 52 and married.  She has a daughter and two sons. The daughter and the first son study at the university and the second son is at school.  Jumakul sells clothes in her store and her husband works as an operator for the bus station. Jumakul started her business seventeen years ago with the initial investment of 5,000 KGS. In the beginning she sold clothes at the market, and then she saved money and moved to the store. She makes about $860 per month. That profit made it possible for her to save money and open three more trading places and purchase a house in Bishkek.  With money received from the loan she wants to purchase school uniforms to sell in order increase the turnover of her business. 

Kulushkan B., 52, is married. She has a daughter and a son, both of whom are at school. Her husband is a farmer. Kulushkan rents a small shop, where she sells clothes and shoes. She started her business activity sixteen years ago with the initial investment of 3,000 KGS and now she makes approximately $645 per month. That profit made it possible for her to save money and start building a new house. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase school uniforms to sell to increase the turnover of her business.  In the future Kulushkan wants to expand her business, open a big store and build a house in Bishkek.

Mairash C. is the treasurer of the group. She is 44 and married. She has two sons and three daughters. The older son and the first daughter study at the medical university and the other children are at school. Mairash owns a store where she sells clothes and shoes. She started her business eighteen years ago with the initial investment of 8,000 KGS and now she earns about $1075 per month. That profit made it possible for her to purchase a flat in Bishkek and pay for her children’s education.  With money received from the loan she wants to purchase school uniforms to sell in her store.  In the future she plans to build a house for her older son.

Raya A., 43, is married. She has a son and two daughters. The first daughter studies at the university, the son is at school and the second daughter is preschool age (under 7).  In 1999, because of the high unemployment rate, Raya started selling clothes. She started with the initial investment of 20,000 KGS and now she earns approximately $430 per month. That profit made it possible for her to start building a new house and purchase a vehicle. In the near future, Raya is going to celebrate her first daughter’s wedding. She hopes to obtain the loan because she needs money to purchase a variety of goods to be ready for such an important event.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused micro-finance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only micro-finance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. 

To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase school uniforms to sell

loans.name: Mbogo Bakyara Twimukye, Ibanda Group

texts.en:
Jonabu N. is the member of Mbogo Bakyara Twimukye group in Ibanda. With his main source of revenue for the past 12 years coming from the sale of food stuffs in Mbogo trading centre, Ibanda, the hardworking and patient Jonabu N. has managed to sustain his family of four children. The 49-year-old dynamic businessman has reached a point where profits accruing to his business now amount to 180,000 Ugandan shillings per a month. With steady progress in building his small enterprise, Jonabu feels that his future prospects are rising every passing day.

With this loan, Jonabu intends to buy more produce including maize, cassava, peanuts, millet, beans and rice so that he does not run short of stock and supplies. This will improve his sales revenue and enable him to maintain a self-sustaining life as he looks at educating his children so that they become important people capable of supporting themselves in the near future.

loans.use: To purchase more food produce for resale

loans.name: Fidele

texts.fr: N. Fidèle est homme né en 1982 à Kamonyi, ancien préfecture de Gitarama, il vit actuellement en province de Kigali, capital du Rwanda. Il est jeune marié, Il fait le commerce de viande à Nyabugogo  en secteur de Muhima. Avec le prêt il veut acheter une vache pour viande de son boucherie, la clientèle des viandes est permanant car il les fournit des restaurent qui lui payent mensuellement. Les mouvements des clients   lui permettent de vider très rapidement le stock et avoir la nécessité d’acheter beaucoup des vaches à abattre et vendre beaucoup des viandes. Les épargnes continuelles lui permet de la survie de sa famille en payant le loyer, dans l’avenir il veut avoir sa propre maison car il loue, et planifier pour le bon futur de  sa famille.
texts.en:
Fidèle N. was born in 1982 in Kamonyi, in the former prefecture of Gitarama, and he currently lives in the province of Kigali, the capital of Rwanda. A young married man, he trades in meat at Nyabugogo in the sector of Muhima. With this loan, he wants to buy a cow to supply meat for his butcher's shop. He has regular meat customers because he supplies restaurants and he is paid monthly. Because of his customers' transactions, he quickly depletes his stock and needs to buy more cows to slaughter and to sell much more meat. He has been able to meet the needs of his family and pay the rent by continually saving. In the future, he would like to buy his own house as he currently rents, and he would like to plan for his family's future.

Translated from French by Sarah Puchner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a cow to slaughter and have meat

loans.name: Robina

texts.en:
Robinah, a married mother of three children, all students, also takes care of additional family members. Robinah owns a store in Kisaasi market where she sells charcoal to all categories of people both on a retail and wholesale basis. She uses public transport to buy bags of charcoal from Nakasongola district in central northern Uganda, and her business challenges include the rainy season and transportation. Aspiring to expand her business so that she can sell wholesale exclusively, she decided to work with MCDT because she wanted additional capital for her business. She wants to use this loan to buy more bags of charcoal.

Robinah resides in and owns a house, and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees and food.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Bernard

texts.en:
Twenty-six-year-old Bernard Okang'a O. is married and has two children, three and two years old; he and his wife hope to give their children a good education to the university level. Operating a business selling such items as padlocks, torches, knives, belts, mirrors and sunglasses located in a very busy place at Kakamega, Bernard sells to walk-ins and repeat customers. In business for two years now, he says that this business is profitable and the major challenge he has are financial constraints. However, he works very hard from early morning to late evening to keep his business doing well.

He is using his loan of Kes 60,000 to buy more padlocks, umbrellas, knives, bolts, mirrors and sunglasses and hopes to be a wholesaler in the future. He describes himself as ambitious and patient.

loans.use: To purchase padlocks, torches, knives, belts, mirrors and sunglasses

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice is married with two children and all of them attend school.  She doesn’t take care of additional family members.  Beatrice owns a stall in Bwaise market selling bananas. She has been in this business for four years. She plans to use this loan to buy more bunches of bananas.  

Beatrice sells to all categories of people. She works six days a week with no additional income and depends on this job for a living. Her business challenge is the  transportation of supplies of bananas from Masaka Villages to her stall  in Bwaise.  Beatrice aspires to sell at wholesale only.  She decided to work with MCDT because she wanted additional capital. She resides in and owns a house and the family has access to electricity but with no piped water. Her monthly expenses includes school and food.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas

loans.name: Rwengiri Modern, Ibanada Group

texts.en:
A determined, hard working M. Immaculate, aged 28 years, has been operating a retail shop business selling general merchandise especially for home use like; plastics, grocery, sugar, salt and more from Ibanda Town. She started this business 2 years ago with her own savings and at the end of every month she is able to pocket profits to the tune of 80,000 Ugandan shillings. 

The small profit is due to her main drawback of having a small stock in business that cannot match the purchasing rate of the customers. Immaculate is therefore seeking a loan that will help her stock more goods to satisfy the customers’ high demand and also transform her enterprise into a larger one. 

Being very committed to the business and with good customer care, she hopes to increase her sales revenue. This will bring about a transformation in her business as she hopes to turn it into a wholesale business which will enable her to achieve a self sustaining life and meet her personal requirements.

loans.use: business restocking

loans.name: Swagila

texts.en:
Swagila is married with four children and all of them are at school. She doesn’t take care of additional family members.  She lives in Najjanankumbi, along the Entebbe road and that is also where she works from. Swagila owns a shop selling second hand clothes. She buys these clothes from the Owino market and uses public transport to and from shopping. She goes shopping for supplies once a week. 

Swagila wants to use this loan to buy more bales of second hand clothes.  She has been in this business for over ten years.  She sells to all categories of people but mainly women.  She has no additional source of livelihood and works six days a week.  She depends on this job for a living. 

She resides in and rents a house which has electricity and piped water. She aspires to import second hand clothes and also building her own house. She decided to work with MCDT because of their good  customer care.   Her business  challenges are transportation and seasonality. She resides in and rents a two roomed house and the family has access to electricity and piped water.   Her monthly expenses includes food, rent and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more bales of second hand clothes

loans.name: Bwenda Bakyara Twimukye. Ibanda Group

texts.en:
Hard working and die hard agriculturalist Simon B., aged 46, has been maintaining a banana plantation, a coffee plantation and cereal crop growing for more than 16 years in his home area of Bwenda, Ibanda. This fetches him 160,000 Ugandan shillings per month from banana sales though not enough to sustain his family of 4 children. Some of his children are still students at different institutions of learning.

Simon has persevered to keep the enterprise growing and his aim for making this loan is to enable him to buy mulch and manure for his plantations. He e plans to  transport his products to bigger markets. This loan will help him increase his productivity and also earn more revenue to be able to live a more sustaining life. He inherited this business from his parents. He is such a devoted man that has keep the business going for all this while.

loans.use: buying mulch and manure for the banana plantation

loans.name: Bernard

texts.en: Bernard K. is twenty eight years old, married and has two children aged eight years and three years old. His business is located at Mukuru kwa Njenga, a busy business environment and he is served by the Kitengela branch. He has been selling such items as power cables, bulbs, bulb holders and other items. He sells to the local people. He has been doing this business for five years now and has one employee. He says that this business is profitable and the major challenge he has is that there are so many people in the area doing the same kind of business as hiscustomers are spoiled of choice. However, he works very hard to keep his business doing well. He is using his loan of Kes 60,000 to buy more cables, bulbs, bulb holders and generally restock to grow his business and meet his customer needs. He hopes to own a car and a house some day. He describes himself as business-minded, hardworking, kind and focused.

loans.use: T buy electronic supplies for resale

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace W. is 21 years old and married to a mechanic. She has one child who does not go to school. She is currently in the business of selling beans, pulses, rice and maize flour at the market. Grace is requesting a loan to stock more bags of maize flour and beans to sell. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to set up a store for her goods.

loans.use: To stock more bags of maize flour and beans to sell

loans.name: Petita Marivel

texts.en:
Petita Marivel M. C. is 40 years old. She is single and lives with her children in Chillanes in the Bolivar Province. Petita has 2 children who are 14 and four years old.

Petita is a member of the rural loan group San Jose del Eden. The group is located about an hour and a half from the town of San Jose del Tambo. The group consists of 20 members, the majority of whom work in agriculture.  

Petita works in agriculture and raises pigs. She does the buying and selling of her products in the nearby town of Matilde Esther.

Petita plans to use the loan to grow corn and cacao. With the help of the loan, she hopes to become more productive in her agricultural production. Her goal within the next 5 years is to have her own house. 

When she is not working, she spends time in the house doing domestic chores.

loans.use: To grow corn and cacao

loans.name: Elizaphan

texts.en:
Elizaphan is a farmer from Kisii town in Western Kenya. He has been practising mixed farming for over 20 years and employs one farmhand. His main products are milk, maize, beans, millet, eggs, vegetables and tomatoes, which he sells to the local market and to schools. He is also a bursar at a local school.
Elizaphan recently completed his second loan from Kiva partner, Juhudi Kilimo, of 50,000 KES and has requested this loan of 80,000 KES to purchase a dairy cow and connect electricity to his house. With the proceeds from this loan, he will be able to provide for his family and have electricity in his house. He is happy that his children will be able to study comfortably when they have an electricity connection.
Elizaphan's primary challenge has been lack of sufficient capital for expansion. However, he plans to expand his cereal business and be the major supplier to various schools in the locality.
Elizaphan is 44 years old. He is married and has been blessed with four children who are now between the ages of eight and sixteen. All the children attend school. He is requesting a bigger loan from Juhudi Kilimo and appreciates how far the organization has brought him to date.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow and connect electricity to his house

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose K. is 47 years old and married to a peasant. She has three children who all go to school. Rose is currently in the business of selling food such as bags of rice, maize flour and sorghum. She is requesting a loan to stock more bags of maize and cassava. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy some goats and sheep to raise at home.

loans.use: To stock more bags of maize and cassava

loans.name: Rosa Angelica

texts.en:
Rosa Angelica C. M. is 61 years old. She lives in Chillanes, in the Bolivar Province of Ecuador. Rosa has 5 children, ages 41, 37, 35, 34, and 33. 

Rosa is a member of the rural loan group ¨San Jose del Eden.¨ The group is located about an hour and a half from the town of San Jose del Tambo. The group consists of 20 members. Most of the group, including Rosa, work in agriculture. Rosa buys and sells products in the nearby town of Matilde Esther.

Rosa hopes to use the loan to buy compost for her cacao crops. The loan would enable her to be more productive. In the next five years, her goal is to improve her home and add a well for water.

She spends her free time in the house doing domestic chores.

loans.use: Purchase compost for cacao crops

loans.name: Margret

texts.en: Margret K. is 59 years old and a widow. She has seven children, none of whom go to school. Margret is currently in the business of selling charcoal from home. She is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her family.

loans.use: To stock more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Enrique Stalin

texts.en:
Enrique Stalin M. A. is 37 years old. He lives in Chillanes in Bolivar Province of Ecuador. He has 3 children, ages 13, 10, and 4 years old. Enrique is a member of the rural loan group ¨San Jose del Eden.¨ The group is located about an hour and a half from the town of San Jose del Tambo. The group consists of 20 members, the majority of whom work in agriculture.  

Enrique works in agriculture and has a fish farm. He does the buying and selling of his products in the nearby town of Matilde Esther. Enrique plans to use the loan to grow cacao. He hopes that with the help of the loan, his agricultural activity will be more productive. His dream is that his children will receive a good education. 

He likes to play sports during his free time.

loans.use: to grow cacao

loans.name: Annet

texts.en:
Annet owns a stall in Kisaasi market selling Irish potatoes. In addition to this business, she is a part-time teacher in a nearby primary school. Annet has been in business for two years. She sells to all categories of people on wholesale. She wants to use her loan to buy more bags of Irish potatoes. She buys bags of potatoes from Kasese district and uses public transport to and from Kasese. She works seven days a week and depends on this job for a living. Her business challenges include transportation and defaulters.
Annet's aspiration is to see her business grow bigger and to make enough profits to buy a delivery van. She decided to join Kiva partner, MCDT SACCO, because it brings services nearer to her.
Annet is married with one child who is not yet in school. She doesn’t take care of additional family members. She lives in and owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more bags of Irish potatoes

loans.name: Sabina

texts.en: Sabina J. is 35 years old and married to a peasant. She has three children who all go to school. Sabina is currently in the business of selling bags of charcoal at the market. She is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal and some firewood to sell. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to expand her business by stocking bamboo and grass for house building.

loans.use: To stock more bags of charcoal and some firewood

loans.name: Javier Arnulfo

texts.en:
Javier Arnulfo L. M. is 32 years old. He lives in a common-law marriage in Chillanes in Bolivar Province of Ecuador. He has 3 children, ages 8, 6, and 3 years old. Javier is a member of the rural loan group ¨San Jose del Eden.¨ The group is located about an hour and a half from the town of San Jose del Tambo. The group consists of 20 members, the majority of whom work in agriculture.  

Javier works in agriculture and raises chickens. He has been producing cacao, coffee, corn, and rice for the past 14 years. He does the buying and selling of his products in the nearby town of Matilde Esther.

Javier plans to use the loan to improve his agricultural productivity by purchasing fertilizer and compost.  His goal for the next 5 years is to have more land and to produce more crops. 

He enjoys the annual festivals of the patron saint San Jose.

loans.use: to buy compost and fertilizer to improve agricultural productivity

loans.name: Ankil Devi

texts.en:
This is 64-year-old Ankil Devi S.. She is married and has one child, aged 27. In 2006, Ankil Devi established a small restaurant business. Working seven hours a day, seven days a week, she is able to support her family. Ankil Devi has already received and successfully repaid five loans from Kiva partner, Patan Business and Professional Women, and used her most recent loan to purchase food ingredients. In the future, Ankil Devi plans to improve her family's economic condition. She thanks you for your support.
Whether on the streets of Kathmandu or in the villages outside of the capital, tea shops are places of business and meeting in Nepal. Called a chiya pasal, these tea shops make a sweet, milky tea that can be purchased for a few cents a cup. With a Kiva loan, Patan Business and Professional Women's borrowers are able to keep their store shelves stocked while increasing their profit margins by buying in greater volume.

About Patan Business and Professional Women
This loan was administered by Kiva's local partner MFI, Patan Business and Professional Women. Patan BPW became Kiva's first field partner in Nepal in 2007. Patan BPW operates throughout the Kathmandu Valley, offering microcredit and business training programs to low-income women. In addition to providing economic opportunity to its clients, Patan BPW seeks to empower Nepali women within the home and community.

loans.use: To buys goods and materials

loans.name: James

texts.en:
N. James is a 54-year-old peasant farmer who grows food crops and owns a banana plantation. He normally sells his produce to grocery and restaurant businesses. James is very hardworking and determined to achieve his goal of owning a large agricultural farm in his home area of Kyarurera, Ibanda. 
With his strong attribute of determination and hardworking skills, James has gotten his 20-year-old enterprise a dependable niche. He makes monthly profits from banana and milk sales to the tune of 150,000 UGX. With this loan, he hopes to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs for next season. He also wants to buy a plot of land. This will improve his yields and therefore his sales revenue, and he will be able to live a more satisfying life and educate his children, which is his main goal.

loans.use: To purchase farm inputs, such as fertilizers and manure, as well as a plot of land

loans.name: Yanet

texts.es:
Yanet nació en la ciudad de Ocongate provincia de Quispicanchis del departamento del Cusco. Actualmente, Yanet vive en la ciudad de Yanama. (La ciudad de Ocongate se encuentra ubicada a dos horas de la ciudad del Cusco y la ciudad de Yanama se encuentra a diez minutos de la ciudad de Ocongate).

Yanet estudio en el instituto pedagógico “San Ignacio de Loyola” la carrera profesional de educación. Actualmente, Yanet trabaja en el colegio “405185” de la comunidad de Chaupimayo y enseña a los niños que están cursando el segundo grado de primaria. Ya son 7 años que se dedica a su profesión y le va muy bien gracias al empeño que le pone en su trabajo.
       
Yanet vivía en la comunidad de Cajamarca donde tenía una pequeña librería, pero ella se mudo a la ciudad de Yanama donde actualmente vive junto con su mamá y sus hermanos. Yanet es una persona muy emprendedora, amigable y carismática, ella quiere volver abrir la pequeña librería pero en la comunidad de Yanama y por ese motivo requiere el préstamo. La pueden encontrar en el colegio los 7 días de la semana, desde las 8 de la mañana hasta las 2  de la tarde. 
 
Con el próximo préstamo, Yanet que espera recibir S/. 2 000.00 nuevo soles. Le gustaría emplear el dinero de este préstamo en comprar mercadería como por ejemplo cuadernos, lapiceros, reglas y muchas cosas más que falta en la librería. 

Ya son dos años que participa en el banco comunal “Las Margarita Ocongate” de la asociación Arariwa Cusco y le va muy bien gracias a la confianza de sus compañeros y a la puntualidad de los pagos de las cuotas. El sueño de la socia es abrir más librerías.

La socia se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Yanet was born in the city of Ocongate, which is in Quispicanchis Province in the department of Cusco. Currently, Yanet lives in the city of Yanama. (Ocongate is located two hours from the city of Cusco, and Yanama is ten minutes away from Ocongate). Yanet studied the teaching profession at the San Ignacio de Loyola teaching institute. Currently, Yanet works at school 405185 in the community of Chaupimayo and teaches second graders. She has been teaching for seven years now, and it has gone very well for her thanks to the effort that she puts into her work. Yanet used to live in the community of Cajamarca where she had a small bookstore, but she moved to Yanama where she currently lives with her mother and siblings. Yanet is a very enterprising, friendly and charismatic person. She wants to reopen her small bookstore in Yanama, and she needs the loan for this reason. She can be found at the school seven days per week, from eight in the morning until two in the afternoon. With this next loan, Yanet expects to receive 2000 new soles. She would like to use the loan money to buy merchandise like notebooks, ballpoint pens, rulers and many other things the bookstore needs. For two years now she has been a member of the “Las Margarita Ocongate” communal bank of Asociación Arariwa Cusco, and it has gone very well for her thanks to the trust of her companions and the punctuality of the loan payments. This member's dream is to open more bookstores. She is grateful for the opportunity given to her through this medium, and she promises to make her payments on schedule.

Translated from Spanish by Danielle Maxson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy notebooks, ballpoint pens, rulers and other items

loans.name: Julio Olmedo

texts.en:
Julio Olmedo N. is 43 years old. He lives in Chillanes in Bolivar Province in Ecuador. He has 4 children, ages 25, 23, 16, and 8 years old. Julio is a member of the rural loan group ¨San Jose del Eden.¨ The group is located about an hour and a half from the town of San Jose del Tambo. The group consists of 20 members, the majority of whom work in agriculture.  

Julio works in agriculture. He does the buying and selling of his products in the nearby town of Matilde Esther. Julio plans to use the loan to maintain his cacao crops. With the help of the loan he hopes to become more productive in his agricultural business. His dream is to buy a house within the next five years. 

In his free time, he likes to play sports and enjoys the annual community festivals of the patron saint San Juan.

loans.use: to maintain his cacao crops

loans.name: Raphael

texts.en:
Raphael is 54 years old, married, and has six children between the ages of 12 and 27. Four of the children attend school. Raphael has been operating his mixed farm in Kisii town, Western Kenya, for over 30 years. He employs two people from his community. His farm produces bananas, tobacco, maize, sukuma wiki (kale), beans and tomatoes, which he sells to the local market. He also earns income from his rental houses in the same area.
Raphael recently completed his previous loan from Kiva partner, Juhudi Kilimo, and has requested this loan of 70,000 KES to purchase farm supplies and start a cereals business. He says that this loan will enable him to expand his farm and therefore provide enough food for his family. He will also be able to earn extra income from the cereals business.
Raphael's primary challenges are lack of fertilizers, diseases, and lack of market especially when there is surplus produce. He hopes that in five years' time, his business will have improved and he will have expanded his farming activities.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies and start a cereals business

loans.name: Laxmi

texts.en:
This is 40-year-old Laxmi N.. She is married and has four children aged 15, 18, 21 and 24. In 1990, Laxmi established a kitchen utensils business. Working eight hours a day, seven days a week, she is able to support her family. Laxmi has already received and successfully repaid five loans from Kiva partner, Patan Business and Professional Women, and used her most recent loan to purchase kitchen utensils for her shop. In the future, Laxmi plans to improve the economic condition of her family. She thanks you for your support.
In Nepal, large supermarkets are rare. Instead, most items can be found in the small, densely packed pasals that line the streets of every city and village. Piled high with utensils, paper goods, and anything else one would need, these stores are your one-stop shop in Nepal. Although usually packed into a space no larger than 100 square feet, these stores carry a sizable and diverse inventory. With the help of a Kiva loan, pasal owners are able to keep inventory up and their customers happy. Competition is fierce, but with extra capital and a bit of creativity, the opportunity for profit is there.

About Patan Business and Professional Women
This loan was administered by Kiva's local partner MFI, Patan Business and Professional Women. Patan BPW became Kiva's first field partner in Nepal in 2007. Patan BPW operates throughout the Kathmandu Valley, offering microcredit and business training programs to low-income women. In addition to providing economic opportunity to its clients, Patan BPW seeks to empower Nepali women within the home and community.

loans.use: To buy kitchen utensils for her shop

loans.name: Edward

texts.en:
Edward, from the town of Kisii in Western Kenya, is 34, married, and has three children between the ages of 2½ and 7. Two of the children attend school. Edward has had a mixed farm which produces maize, bananas and milk for the last five years, selling his products to the local market. He also earns income from his rental houses in the same area.

Edward has requested this loan of 70,000 Kenyan Shillings from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase a dairy cow and improve his cattle-selling business. He says this loan will help him acquire a quality dairy cow that will increase his milk production. He will therefore be able to provide enough milk for domestic consumption and earn enough income that will assist him in paying school fees for his children.

His biggest challenge has been the fluctuations in product prices that make it hard to budget. He is, however, grateful to Juhudi for taking the family from poverty and uplifting their living standards by giving them loans.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: Marilu Dolores

texts.es:
Marilu nació en la ciudad de Urubamba provincia de Urubamba del departamento del Cusco. Actualmente, Marilu vive en la misma ciudad donde nació. (La ciudad de Urubamba se encuentra ubicada a una hora diez de la ciudad del Cusco). 
 
Marilu se dedica a la venta de leña, madera y arboles. Ya son 15 años que se dedica al negocio y le va muy bien gracias al empeño que le pone en su trabajo.
       
Con el próximo préstamo, Marilu que espera recibir S/. 2000 nuevo soles. Le gustaría emplear el dinero de este préstamo en comprar mercadería como por ejemplo madera y leña. 

Ya son varios años que participa en el banco comunal “Vilcanota” de la asociación Arariwa Cusco y le va muy bien gracias a la confianza de sus compañeros y a la puntualidad de los pagos de las cuotas. 

La socia se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Marilu was born in the city of Urubamba, Urubamba Province in the department of Cusco. Currently, Marilu lives in the city where she was born. (The city of Urubamba is located an hour and ten minutes from the city of Cusco.) Marilu sells firewood, wood and trees. She has been in this business for 15 years now, and she has done very well thanks to the effort she puts into her work. With this next loan, Marilu hopes to receive 2000 new soles. She would like to invest the loan money in buying merchandise like wood and firewood. For several years now she has been a member of the Vilcanota communal bank of Asociación Arariwa Cusco, and she is doing very well thanks to the trust of her companions and the punctuality of their loan payments. This member is grateful for the opportunity given to her through this medium, and she promises to make her payments as scheduled.

Translated from Spanish by Danielle Maxson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise like wood and firewood

loans.name: Rita

texts.en: This is 31-year-old Rita N. who is married and has two children aged 14 and 2. In 1995, Rita established her tailoring business. Working seven days a week and five hours a day, she supports her family. Rita has already received and successfully repaid one loan from Patan BPW. She used this new loan to purchased raw materials for her tailoring business. In the future, she plans to uplift the economic condition of her family. She thanks you for your support. In the Kathmandu Valley, clothing is made to order. Tailors’ stalls line the streets where store owners sell material and work their sewing machines. These skilled tailors make school uniforms for children as well as the the traditional women's kurta surwal and men's daura surwal. With a Kiva loan, Patan BPW borrowers are able to purchase additional cloth material or sewing machines that will increase their production and profitability. About Patan BPW: This loan was administered by Kiva's local partner in Nepal: micro-finance institution, Patan Business and Professional Women. Patan BPW became Kiva's first field partner in Nepal in 2007. It operates throughout the Kathmandu Valley, offering microcredit and business training programs to low-income women. In addition to providing economic opportunity to its clients, Patan BPW seeks to empower N. women within the home and community.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for her tailoring business

loans.name: Maria Perpetua

texts.en:
Maria Perpetua B. A. is 56 years old. She lives in Chillanes in the Bolivar Province of Ecuador. She has 3 children, ages 35, 28, and 20 years old. Maria is a member of the rural loan group ¨San Jose del Eden.¨ The group is located about an hour and a half from the town of San Jose del Tambo. The group consists of 20 members, the majority of whom work in agriculture.  

Maria works in agriculture and raises farm animals. She does the buying and selling of her products in the nearby town of Matilde Esther. She plans to use the loan to grow cacao. Her dream for the next five years is to be productive in her agricultural activities. 

She enjoys cooking.

loans.use: to buy compost and fertilizer for cacao

loans.name: Daysi Rosalvina

texts.es:
Daysi nació en la ciudad de Arequipa y actualmente vive en la ciudad de Urubamba del departamento del Cusco. (La ciudad de Urubamba se encuentra ubicada a una hora diez de la ciudad del Cusco). 
 
Daysi se dedica a la venta de zapatos y ropa a pedido del cliente. Ya son varios años que se dedica al negocio y le va muy bien gracias al empeño que le pone en su trabajo.
       
Con el próximo préstamo, Daysi que espera recibir S/. 3000 nuevo soles. Le gustaría emplear el dinero de este préstamo en comprar mercadería como por ejemplo zapatos de marca. 

Ya son varios años que participa en el banco comunal “Vilcanota” de la asociación Arariwa y le va muy bien gracias a la confianza de sus compañeros y a la puntualidad de los pagos de las cuotas. 

La socia se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Daysi was born in Arequipa and now lives in the city of Urubamba in the department of Cusco. (Urumbamba is located one hour and ten minutes away from the city of Cusco.) Daysi sells shoes and clothes on request from her customers. She has been doing this for many years and has been successful, thanks to the effort she puts in her work. With this next loan, Daysi is asking for 3000 new soles ($1075). She wants to use this money to buy merchandise, such as brand-name shoes. She has been a part of the Arariwa Association's "Vilcanota" community bank for a number of years and has done well, thanks to her comrades' trust and her punctual payments. Daysi would like to thank you for the opportunity provided by these loans, and she promises to meet her payments on schedule.

Translated from Spanish by Ross Forman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise, such as brand-name shoes.

loans.name: Anju

texts.en: This is 28-year-old Anju N.. She is married and has one child aged 12. In 1998, she established her tailoring business and, working seven days a week and five hours a day, she supports her family. Anju has already received and successfully repaid two loans from Patan BPW. She used this most recent loan to purchase raw materials for her tailoring business. In the future, she plans to uplift the economic condition of her family. She thanks you for your support. In the Kathmandu Valley, clothing is made to order. Tailors’ stalls line the streets where store owners sell material and work their sewing machines. These skilled tailors make school uniforms for children as well as the the traditional women's kurta surwal and men's daura surwal. With a Kiva loan, Patan BPW borrowers are able to purchase additional cloth material or sewing machines that will increase their production and profitability. About Patan BPW: This loan was administered by Kiva's local partner in Nepal: micro-finance institution, Patan Business and Professional Women. Patan BPW became Kiva's first field partner in Nepal in 2007. It operates throughout the Kathmandu Valley, offering microcredit and business training programs to low-income women. In addition to providing economic opportunity to its clients, Patan BPW seeks to empower N. women within the home and community.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for her tailoring business

loans.name: Camino Al Triunfo Group

texts.en:
The communal bank “Camino al Triunfo” (The Walk to Triumph) consists of 18 associates from Temuco City. This is the second loan they seek from Kiva lenders. These individuals' livelihoods consists of sales of seasonings (garlic, oregano, and merkén), canned goods, fast foods (fried pies, buns and completos (Traditional Chilian Hot Dogs), lingerie, perfumes, and home décor items (sheets, towels, tablecloths).

Jacqueline can be found in the third row and first from the left; she is wearing a green jacket. Jacqueline´s business consists of a small grocery store located in front of her house.  Jacqueline has managed this store for the past 15 years.  Jacqueline plans to use this loan to purchase merchandise such as perishable and non-perishable food items for her store.  As the market has been getting more competitive, she would like to offer a greater variety and change some of the items she currently offers; for example, a larger variety of vegetables, firewood and charcoal items. 

Even though Jacqueline is affected by thyroid disease, she remains full of life due to her business. Jacqueline's household consists of her mother and her 19-year-old daughter, who also works.  Jacqueline also has an 18-year-old son who is serving in the military. 

What Jacqueline has found most appealing about Fondo Esperanza is that they are quick to inform her about the progress of her loan. 

Temuco is the capital of the Araucanía region. It is located 670 kilometers south of Santiago (the capital of Chile) and is the location for a number of lakeside spa resorts and striking native flora and fauna. This region is also noteworthy for being the region where 50% of Chile's existing indigenous Mapuche community live; some of whom are members of Fondo Esperanza communal banks.

loans.use: Perishable and non-perishable food items

loans.name: Maruja

texts.es:
Maruja nació en la ciudad de Cusco y actualmente vive en la ciudad de Urubamba del departamento del Cusco. (La ciudad de Urubamba se encuentra ubicada a una hora diez de la ciudad del Cusco). 
 
Maruja trabaja como empleada pública en la UGEL (Unidad de Gestión Educativo del Local), ella trabaja de lunes a viernes desde las 7 de la mañana hasta las 3 de tarde. Maruja nos cuenta que su papá trabajaba en la fábrica donde confeccionaba frazadas pero a su papá lo despidieron y la empresa le indemnizó  con frazadas entonces Maruja como venia que había mercadería entonces decidió vender las frazadas. Ya son 15 años que se dedica al negocio y le va muy bien gracias al empeño que le pone en su trabajo.
       
Con el próximo préstamo Maruja que espera recibir S/. 1000 nuevo soles. Le gustaría emplear el dinero de este préstamo en comprar mercadería como por ejemplo frazadas. 

Ya son varios años que participa en el banco comunal “Vilcanota” de la asociación Arariwa y le va muy bien gracias a la confianza de sus compañeros y a la puntualidad de los pagos de las cuotas. 

La socia se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Maruja was born in Cusco and now lives in the city of Urubamba. (Urubamba is located one hour and ten minutes away from the city of Cusco). Maruja works as a civil servant at the local educational authority. She works from Mondays to Fridays from 7 am to 3 pm. Maruja tells us that her father worked in a blanket-making factory, but he was fired and was paid in blankets as compensation. Therefore, Maruja set up a business selling blankets. She has been doing this for the last 15 years, thanks to the efforts she puts in her work. With this next loan, Maruja is asking for 1000 new soles ($375). She will spend the money on buying merchandise. She has been a member of the Arariwa Association's "Vilcanota" community bank for a number of years and has done well thanks to her comrades' trust in her and her punctual payments. Maruja thanks you for contributing to this loan and promises to pay on time according to schedule.

Translated from Spanish by Ross Forman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise, such as blankets

loans.name: Eloy Rodolfo

texts.en:
Eloy Rodolfo M. C. is 38 years old. He lives in Chillanes in the Bolivar Province of Ecuador. He has one child aged 16 years old. Eloy is a member of the rural loan group ¨San Jose del Eden.¨ The group is located about an hour and a half from the town of San Jose del Tambo. The group consists of 20 members, the majority of whom work in agriculture.  

Eloy works in agriculture. He does the buying and selling of his products in the nearby town of Matilde Esther. He plans to use the loan to buy fertilizer for his cacao crops. His dream is to buy a plot of land within the next five years. 

He spends his free time doing household chores and taking care of his animals.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer for his cacao crops

loans.name: Tara Devi

texts.en: This is 28-year-old Tara Devi P.. She is married and has two children aged 15 and 12. In 2000, she established her vegetable-farming business and, working seven days a week and five hours a day, she supports her family. Tara Devi has already received and successfully repaid one loan from Patan BPW. She used this most recent loan to purchase seed and fertilizers for her business. In the future, she plans to uplift the economic condition of her family. She thanks you for your support. Over 70% of Nepal's economy is agricultural. Typically, Nepali households grow crops on small plots of terraced land. Rice (bhat), lentils (daal), and vegetables (thakari) are the staples of the Nepali diet. With a Kiva loan, Patan BPW's borrowers are able to purchase greater amounts of seed and fertilizer, which enables them to grow cash crops to sell in the local market. Such crops allow households to move beyond subsistence and provide much-needed cash income throughout the year. About Patan BPW: This loan was administered by Kiva's local partner in Nepal: micro-finance institution, Patan Business and Professional Women. Patan BPW became Kiva's first field partner in Nepal in 2007. It operates throughout the Kathmandu Valley, offering microcredit and business training programs to low-income women. In addition to providing economic opportunity to its clients, Patan BPW seeks to empower Nepali women within the home and community.

loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Urkupiña Group

texts.es:
“URKUPIÑA” es el nombre de una Asociación Comunal que está iniciando su primer ciclo en el Centro Focal de Panamericana, cuenta con nueve integrantes, ocho socias y un varón.

La presidenta de la asociación, Silvia es madre de tres niños, se dedica a la artesanía en joyas. Ella aprendio este oficio en un Curso de Joyería que pasó hace tres años, para reforzar este aprendizaje ve  programas de la televisión que tratan de la elaboración de joyas.  Su primer préstamo es para la compra de material.

Las otras personas que integran la asociación comunal tienen negocios diferentes, como: producción de chompas y chalinas, ventas de cosméticos, elaboración y venta de muebles, venta de madera, venta de cosméticos en variedad, costura de vaqueros, venta de queso y leche, venta de artículos de limpieza.
texts.en:
“URKUPIÑA” is the name of a community association that is starting its first cycle in the Panamericana center. It has nine new members, 8 women and one man. The association president, Silvia, is the mother of three children. She works in artisanal jewelry. She learned this profession in a jewelry course three years ago. To reinforce what she learned, she watches television programs about making jewelry. Her first loan is to purchase materials. The other people that make up the community association have different businesses, such as: making sweaters and shawls, selling cosmetics, making and selling furniture, selling wood, selling a variety of cosmetics, sewing bluejeans, selling cheese and milk, and selling cleaning items.

Translated from Spanish by Ellen Donohue, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase materials

loans.name: Durga

texts.en: This is 46 year-old Durga R.. She is married and has two children aged 30 and 27. In 1998, she established her vegetable-farming business and, working seven days a week and five hours a day, she supports her family. Durga has already received and successfully repaid two loans from Patan BPW and used this most recent loan to purchase seed and fertilizers for her business. In the future, she plans to uplift the economic condition of her family. She thanks you for your support. Over 70% of Nepal's economy is agricultural. Typically, Nepali households grow crops on small plots of terraced land. Rice (bhat), lentils (daal), and vegetables (thakari) are the staples of the Nepali diet. With a Kiva loan, Patan BPW's borrowers are able to purchase greater amounts of seed and fertilizer, which enables them to grow cash crops to sell in the local market. Such crops allow households to move beyond subsistence and provide much-needed cash income throughout the year. About Patan BPW: This loan was administered by Kiva's local partner in Nepal: micro-finance institution, Patan Business and Professional Women. Patan BPW became Kiva's first field partner in Nepal in 2007. It operates throughout the Kathmandu Valley, offering microcredit and business training programs to low-income women. In addition to providing economic opportunity to its clients, Patan BPW seeks to empower Nepali women within the home and community. For more information about Patan BPW, visit our Patan BPW partner page to keep an eye out for new loans and borrower updates. Also, please join our Patan BPW Lending Team.

loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Dhan Kumari

texts.en:
This is 68-year-old Dhan Kumari T.. She is married and has two children, aged 45 and 46. In 1990, Dhan Kumari established a grocery shop business. Working eight hours a day, seven days a week, she is able to support her family. She has already received and successfully repaid two loans from Kiva partner, Patan Business and Professional Women, and used her most recent loan to purchase grocery goods. In the future, Dhan Kumari plans to improve the economic condition of her family. She thanks you for your support.
In the Kathmandu Valley, the small grocery store, called a pasal, is an important part of the local economy. Fresh produce, milk, and staples such as rice, lentils, and flour are purchased daily for cooking in the home. Owners of small grocery stores use Kiva loans to increase their purchasing power and profit margins. By keeping inventory strong and purchasing in larger amounts, owners of these small stores are able to increase profitability. While a typical pasal might be no more than 100 square feet, they are always full of bargaining customers, in-coming produce, and shrewd businesswomen.

About Patan Business and Professional Women
This loan was administered by Kiva's local partner MFI, Patan Business and Professional Women. Patan BPW became Kiva's first field partner in Nepal in 2007. Patan BPW operates throughout the Kathmandu Valley, offering microcredit and business training programs to low-income women. In addition to providing economic opportunity to its clients, Patan BPW seeks to empower Nepali women within the home and community. For more information about Patan BPW, visit our partner page and keep an eye out for new loans and borrower updates: BPW Partner Page Join our lending team: BPW Lending Team"

loans.use: to buy grocery goods

loans.name: Maria Esther

texts.es:
María de 35 años, ella tiene en su casa una tienda de víveres, , vive en las Orquídeas de Guayaquil (zona urbana, llamada las orquídeas porque en su descubrimiento habían muchas flores orquídeas).

Cuando su esposo fue despedido en la empresa que trabajaba con la liquidación decidió comprar víveres para venderlos con su esposa, poco a poco con esfuerzo readecuaron su casa y ubicaron una pequeña tienda en su casa. Ahora ella trabaja con ayuda de su hijo de 17 años vendiendo víveres. 

Para poder seguir con su negocio quiere comprar bebidas y ropa, en el futuro quiere tener dinero para una tienda mas grande y así asegurar el futuro de su familia.
texts.en:
María is 35 years old. In her house she has a grocery store. She lives in Las Orquídeas de Guayaquil (an urban area, Las Orquídeas because when it was discovered there were a lot of flowers). When her husband was laid off from the business where he worked, he decided to use his severance to buy groceries to sell with his wife. Little by little, with hard work, they were able to remodel their house and they opened a little store there. Now she sells groceries, with the help of her 17 year old son. To be able to continue with her business, she wants to buy beverages and clothes. In the future she wants to have money to have a bigger store and thus ensure her family's future.

Translated from Spanish by Ellen Donohue, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Clothing, rice

loans.name: Esperanza Divina 3 & 4 Group

texts.en:
Dorka is the coordinator of her group, Esperanza Divina 3 & 4 (Divine Hope). She makes her home here in a simple structure with her young child. She says that her most difficult challenge is to build her house.  In the meantime, she enjoys being with her child at home.

Dorka is excited to be taking her eighth loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loans and grown her business. She has had her business for over 5 years, starting with some savings she had and making the plan to start a business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business by buying underwear, pants and accessories. She will use the profits to invest in her business and to save to start building her house in the near future. 

This Esperanza associate began with us because she like how the loans work, the group, the community and the opportunities. Her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in the rural area surrounding Hato Mayor, an agricultural area. This area, like nearly all impoverished areas of the Dominican Republic, suffers from unreliable running water (none of which is potable) and electricity.

loans.use: To buy underwear, pants and accessories

loans.name: Esther Maritza

texts.es:
Esther de 33 años, ella tiene una papelería (en Ecuador se los llama “bazar”) y vive en el Fortín de Guayaquil( zona periurbana, con caminos de tierra y lomas). 

Comenzó hace 3 año con la papelería para poder mantener a su familia, vendiendo cuadernos, plumas y papeles a sus vecinos y conocidos cuando completo el dinero para ubicar su pequeña papelería readecuo su casa y la ubico en la parte delantera de su casa. Trabaja desde las 07h00am hasta las 21h00pm todos los días.  

Con el préstamo quiere comprar cuadernos, plumas y vitrinas para su negocio. En el futuro quiere amplia su negocio, mercadería y que sus cuatro hijos sean profesionales.
texts.en:
Esther is 33 years old and has a paper goods store, (known as a "bazar" in Ecuador). She lives in "Fortín de Guayaquil" (suburban zone made up of land and slopes). Three years ago she began selling notebooks, pens, and paper to her neighbors and acquaintances so that she could support her family. When she saved enough money to start her store, she set up an area in the front part of her home, where she works from 7:00 AM to 7:00 PM every day. She will use the money from this loan to buy notebooks, pens, and display cases for her business. She wants to expand her business in the future and would like her four children to attain professional careers.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Inventory

loans.name: Patricia

texts.en:
Patricia P. is from the village of Rizal. She is 44 years old. Patricia is married and has 4 children. To make a living, Patricia owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling vegetables and  meat in the local community. Patricia has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Patricia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Patricia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Patricia is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 7th loan taken out by Patricia from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Noemi

texts.es: La Señora Noemí se dedica a las labores del hogar, su esposo, el señor Martin es muy trabajador, el trabaja como chofer de un autobús de transporte de personal. Ellos adquirieron una vivienda de interes social y poco a poco y con ahorros han logrado hacerle algunas mejoras, han pensado en construir una habitación mas al frente de la vivienda, es por eso que solicitan este crédito, para empezar la construcción.
texts.en:
Señora Noemí does housework. Her husband, Señor Martin, is very hard-working. He works as a bus driver, transporting passengers. They acquired a house in subsidized public housing, and little by little, using their savings, they have succeeded in making it somewhat better. They have thought about constructing an extra room at the front of the house, and this is why they are applying for this loan, to begin the construction.

Translated from Spanish by Pam McMurry, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Build a room

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy S. is from the village of Bagnos. She is 45 years old. Nancy is married and has 5 children. To make a living, Nancy owns & operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Nancy has been engaged in her business for over 29 years and earns approximately 15,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Nancy joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nancy has successfully repaid a previous loan of 25,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase new items to expand product offering. Nancy is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 12th loan taken out by Nancy from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Maria Guadalupe

texts.es: La señora María tiene una familia muy unida, ella se dedica al hogar, su esposo el señor Francisco, trabaja como obrero en una maquiladora, la señora tiene dos hijos, y ellos también aportan en el gasto familiar, sus hijos también trabajan en una maquiladora.  El señor francisco adquirió una vivienda de interes social y quieren colocarle el Vitro piso, es por eso que requieren de este dinero. Para tener una mejor calidad de vida. Y un mejor patrimonio familiar.
texts.en:
Mrs.María has a very close family. She is devoted to her home and her husband Mr. Francisco works in a factory. She has two children who also contribute financially to the family expenses. Her children also work in a factory. Mr. Francisco bought a government-subsidized home and they would both like to put tiles on their floor. This is why they are requesting this loan. To have a better quality of life and a family home.

Translated from Spanish by Rocio Vargas, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Floor tiles

loans.name: Fermina

texts.en:
