loans.name: Ghafooran's Group

texts.en:
Ghafooran lives in a small city called Kot Radha Kishen. It is located near the city of Kasur and is famous for its dairy products. She lives in a three-room brick house with her family. 

Her husband works in a factory that is located in the city of Karachi. She is the mother of two sons, 21-year-old Z., who left his education after 5th standard and started his business of selling milk by purchasing a dairy cow eight years ago, and 12-year-old Zahid, who is studying in 7th standard.
 
Ghafooran has applied for a loan from Asasah for her elder son. With the loan amount, he will buy another dairy cow to increase the production of milk and expand his business. With increased productivity, he will be able to supply a larger quantity milk to more customers and make more money. 

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and is in her third loan cycle.

loans.use: Purchase another dairy cow for a dairy business

loans.name: Kalsoom's Group

texts.en:
Kalsoom is a resident of Kot Radha Kishen, which is a small city of Pakistan known for its dairy products. She is 32 years old and lives in a single-room brick house with her family.  

She is the mother of 11-year-old Adeel and 9-year-old Sania, who are studying in 8th and 6th class respectively, and 6-year-old Talib. Her youngest son has not started to attend school yet. 

Her husband is an educated person; he completed his education through 10th standard and operates a grocery shop in the market. After coming from the shop, he supplies milk to the milk shops, while Kalsoom takes care of his buffaloes at her home. 

Kalsoom has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband. With the loan amount, he will add groceries to his grocery shop because he has found good profit potential in this business and enjoys working in it. 

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and is in her third loan cycle. She has proved herself a responsible client who never missed a single meeting and paid her installments on time.

loans.use: Purchase groceries for grocery shop

loans.name: Shaheen's Group

texts.en:
Shaheen, aged 40 years, is married with a single son. She is an uneducated lady. She always wanted to get an education but couldn’t due to the poor financial conditions of her family. Her father was the only breadwinner of the family and she has a big family to serve and its difficult to manage the study expenses of her family.
 
Her husband, A. Gamar A., is a salesman by profession. He has 10 years of experience in sales work. Earlier, he sold edible items for someone else, then he started selling medicines as his own business. Now he wants to change his business. He has seen good potential in the grocery business because he can generate a good income on it, which he couldn’t earn by medicine selling. 
 
This family belongs to a city named Kot Radha Kishan in Pakistan. Kot Radha Kishan city is famous for its dairy products. They own a small house of two rooms and have been living in it for over 21 years.
 
Shaheen has applied for a loan for the sixth time from Asasah for her husband. With the loan amount, he will buy the groceries and start a grocery shop in the market. In the previous five years, Shaheen has given no complaints regarding repayments and hasn't missed a single meeting.

loans.use: Purchase groceries to start a grocery shop

loans.name: Riaz's Group

texts.en:
Riaz is a housewife. She is 46 years old and lives in Kot Radha Kishen, which is a small city located in Punjab province of Pakistan. 
Kot Radha Kishen is near Lahore and famous for its dairy products. She owns a small house of three rooms where she lives with her family. 
Riaz is the mother of three sons. Only one of her sons could manage to get ana education. Now the all three of them work in a factory to support the family financially. Her husband is a laborer. He sometimes gets work, sometimes not. That’s why her children started supporting the family. 
Riaz has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband. With the loan, he will start a grocery shop in a nearby market and leave his labor work.  
Riaz is hopeful that a new business will bring new happiness to the family and her family’s financial condition will get better. She is a regular loan user and this is the seventh time she has applied for a loan from Asasah. In previous years, she has proved that she is a very responsible client and always attends meetings.

loans.use: To start a grocery shop

loans.name: Riffat's Group

texts.en:
Riffat is married to S. and belongs to a small city near to Lahore Pakistan called Kot radha kishen. She owns a three room brick house where she lives with her husband and five children. Four of them are daughters and one is a son. 

Her eldest daughter works in a factory. Her all other children stay at home. Riffat and her husband couldn’t educate their children due to poor financial conditions.  

Her husband works as a laborer. It is very difficult to survive as a laborer because it’s not a permanent job: many times her husband doesn’t get work regularly. Riffat wants her husband to start his own grocery shop so he makes a regular income. Therefore, she has applied for a loan from Asasah. With the loan amount her husband will buy groceries in bulk and start a grocery shop in the nearby market.  

Riffat is hopeful that her husband will be able to establish his business very soon and start earning a regular income. 

She wants to marry her eldest daughter who is now of 24 years old. She hopes that with the increased income she will be able to do this soon. She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 5th loan cycle. She has proved herself as a very responsible client and never missed any meetings.

loans.use: starting a grocery store

loans.name: Katharine's Group

texts.en:
Katharine supports her family by doing sewing work. She is a seamstress who sews clothes for her neighboring clients. The reason she started this business is because her husband’s income was not regular and it was very difficult for her family to survive financially. Her husband works as a laborer. 
She is the mother of two daughters and a son. Both of her daughters are nurses and make contributions to improving the financial condition of their family.  

Katharine lives with her family in a three room brick house made of mud in the area of Clarkabad.

She has applied for a loan from Asasah for her sewing business. With the loan she will buy an electric sewing machine and hire a worker who will assist her in completing orders on time. She hopes that by hiring an assistant her business will expand and her income will increase as well. 

Her elder daughter is now of marriage age and Katharine is confident that she will be able to marry her soon with the help of an increased income. 
She is in her 3rd loan cycle and has proved a responsible client of Asasah. In the previous years of loans she has maintained a good credit history and never missed any meetings.

loans.use: buying an electric sewing machine

loans.name: Naziran Begum

texts.en:
Naziran begum is a wife of A. H. and resides in a city called Gujranwala, in Pakistan. Gujranwala city is near to Sialkot which is famous for their sweetmeats.  Naziran belongs to a family of talented people. They all are involved in the shoe making business. Her husband is a cobbler by profession and Naziran started helping him just after her marriage. 

She has three children: two sons and one daughter. Her sons couldn’t get an education because they wanted to support their parents in their business while Naziran and her husband wanted to give a good education to their daughter. By the grace of God, she is enrolled in a school and studying in 10th standard.  

Naziran and her family have been making shoes for many years. They obtain good orders from shoe factories as well as from shoe shops. They enjoy working & helping each other in their work. 

Naziran has applied for a loan from Asasah for her family business. With the loan amount they will buy raw materials such as leather, glue, nails, and shoe polishes in large quantity so they make the shoes in bulk and increase their sales volume. Naziran is hopeful that this investment will help them in increasing their profits and will improve the living standards of her family.

loans.use: purchasing raw material for making shoes

loans.name: Naseem Akhtar

texts.en:
Naseem akhtar is married to A. M. and lives in a city called Lahore which is the second largest city of Pakistan. She owns a three room house and lives with her family in the area called Yadgar. Yadgar is famous for its bus stands. Every bus is easily available at this location. 

She is a very caring wife and a mother as well. She has four children: two sons and two daughters. Her daughters are married and her sons are settled in their own businesses. Her elder son is involved in a dairy business. The younger son runs a grocery shop. 

Naseem feels herself a blissful lady who has a very nice family and disciplined kids who give respect to their elders and obey them. She has applied for a loan from Asasah for her elder son. With the loan amount he will buy another dairy-cow and increase his dairy business. 

Presently, he has a single cow which produces 6-8kg of milk for him which has now become insufficient and is affecting his earnings. He thinks that by buying another cow the milk productivity will definitely increase and he will also increase his sales.  Naseem is an optimistic lady and has a strong belief that her son will surely achieve his plan and will become more successful in his business.

loans.use: purchasing a dairy cow

loans.name: Sharifan

texts.en:
Sharifan is married to M. M. F. and resides in a city called Lahore, the second largest city of Pakistan. She is 38 years old and an educated lady. She couldn’t get an education due to poor the financial condition of her family. Her father was the only breadwinner and had a big family to serve. She mostly stays at home and spends time with her mother by helping her in managing the household chores.  

After her marriage, she has taken care of her responsibilities well and never gives any complaints to her in laws. Her in-laws also live with her and she takes care of their every need and keeps them happy.  

Her husband is involved in the milk-selling business. Presently, he has a single cow who produces 8-10kg milk for him. He sells 1kg milk for 45 Pakistani rupees (PKR) and sells 10kg milk in 450 PKR on a daily basis, which enables him to meet the financial needs of the family. 

Sharifan has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan amount he will buy another dairy-cow because Ramadan (the month when Muslims fast from dawn to sunset) has started and the demand for milk has increased 10 times over, so this is the time when he can make a good income and earns a good profit from it. 

Sharifan is hopeful that her husband will be able to achieve what he plans and will able to improve the living standards of his family.

loans.use: purchasing a dairy-cow

loans.name: Maruja

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “HATUN SONCCO ”; El banco comunal está ubicado en el distrito de Huanchac, provincia de Cusco y departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra.  Maruja, ella tiene  48 años de edad, es natural de Acomayo, ella tiene 3 hijos  La socia  es docente de profesión y ella trabaja en las zonas altas de profesora de inicial, La socia desea arreglar su vivienda y para esto ella está solicitando el préstamo, La socia también se dedica a la crianza de aves y algunas veces los envía a Puerto Maldonado, ella desea también  que la trasladen para el año que viene a Cusco ciudad de este modo ella tendría más tiempo para sus hijos, es una mujer trabajadora y sin el apoyo de nadie sale adelante con mucha fuerza y optimismo.  La socia solicita el préstamo para invertir en arreglar su vivienda.                   

La socia agradece y valora el préstamo otorgado mediante este medio y del mismo modo se compromete en cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
This member belongs to “HATUN SONCCO" community bank, located in Huanchac district in the province and department of Cusco. Her name is Maruja; she is 48 years old, has 3 children, and is originally from Acomayo. She is a teacher by profession and works in the higher zones of the city as a kindergarten teacher. She is requesting a loan to repair her home. Maruja also raises birds and sometimes sends them to Puerto Maldonado. She hopes to move to Cusco city next year to have more time for her children. She's a working mother and has made a lot of progress by herself, with a lot of strength and optimism. Maruja is requesting this loan to fix her house. Maruja appreciates and values this loan opportunity, and is committed to making her repayment within the specified period of time.

Translated from Spanish by Vivian Lu, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Home repair.

loans.name: Gumercinda

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal  “HATUN SONCCO ” ; El banco comunal está ubicado en el distrito de Huanchac,  provincia de Cusco y departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Gumercinda;  ella tiene 52 años de edad, es  casada y tiene 4 hijos;  La socia se dedica a trabajar en sus propio cafetín situado en la calle arco iris;  ella trabaja desde el año 2003 y alterna sus actividades del hogar con este negocio.  La socia desea poder implementar su cafetín y vender más variedades de postres, bebidas frías y calientes; A futuro la socia desearía tener  sucursales en todo Cusco.  La socia solicita el préstamo para invertir en implementar su cafetín. 
                  .
La socia agradece y valora el préstamo otorgado mediante este medio y del mismo modo se compromete en cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
Gumercinda belongs to the community bank, "Hatun Soncco", which is located in the district of Huanchac, in the province of Cusco, in the state of Cusco. Gumercinda is 52 years old, is married and has 4 children. She dedicates herself to running a small cafe on the street "arco iris". She has worked here since 2003 and alternates her household duties with this business. Gumercinda wishes to be able to set up her own cafe and sell more varieties of desserts and hot and cold drinks. In the future, she would like to have branches in all of Cusco. Gumercinda is requesting this loan to invest in setting up her own cafe. She is thankful for and values the loan granted to her and promises to comply with the payment of her installments in the timeline established.

Translated from Spanish by Anne Rodriguez, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To invest in setting up her own cafe

loans.name: Cesar Alberto

texts.es:
El socio pertenece al banco comunal “ HATUN SONCCO ”; El banco comunal está ubicado en el distrito de Huanchac, provincia de Cusco y departamento de Cusco.

El socio es él Sr. César, él tiene  27 años de edad, es soltero y vive con sus hermana mayor; El socio se dedica al comercio, él socio tenía un pequeño cafetín en la universidad andina, le a ido muy bien pero decidió después de muchos años cambiar de negocio y de este modo él socio alquiló un stand en puerto Maldonado y lleva ropa para vender, él socio también fue chofer de autos prestando servicio de taxi durante años,  El socio desea  ahora continuar con su negocio de venta de ropa en Puerto Maldonado.  El socio solicita el préstamo para invertir en comprar y vender ropa.

El socio agradece y valora el préstamo otorgado mediante este medio y del mismo modo se compromete en cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
César belongs to the community bank "Hatun Soncco", which is located in the district of Huanchac, in the province of Cusco, in the state of Cusco. César is 27 years old, single, and lives with his older sister. He dedicates himself to running a small cafe in La Universidad Andina. This has gone very well but after many years, he has decided to change his business. He rented a stand in the Maldonado port and now sells clothing. He is also a driver and has offered a taxi service for many years. Now, César wishes to continue with his business of selling clothing in Port Maldonado. He is requesting this loan to invest in purchasing and selling clothing. César is thankful for and values the loan offered to him and promises to comply with the payment of his installments according to the timeline established.

Translated from Spanish by Anne Rodriguez, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To invest in a new business of purchasing and selling clothing

loans.name: Joseline Anahi

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “HATUN SONCCO ”; El banco comunal está ubicado en el distrito de Huanchac,  provincia de Cusco y departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Joseline;  ella tiene 23  años de edad, es soltera; La socia se dedica a la atención de su bar, ella es empresaria y desde hace 4 años ha estado trabajando en diferentes negocios vendiendo diferentes artículos, cosméticos, dictado de clases para niños  y juntó un pequeño  capital, para invertirlo en el alquiler de un local y la implementación de su bar. La socia desea comprar copas, bebidas, velas y diferentes insumos para implementar el bar, ella también está postulando a la universidad le gustas las artes visuales.  La socia solicita el préstamo para invertir en  la implementación de su bar.

La socia agradece y valora el préstamo otorgado mediante este medio y del mismo modo se compromete en cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
Joseline belongs to the community bank "Hatun Soncco", which is located in the district of Huanchac, in the province of Cusco, in the state of Cusco. Joseline is 23 years old and is single. She dedicates herself to running a bar. She is a businesswoman and for four years she has worked in various businesses, selling various articles, cosmetics, and recordings of classes for children. In this way she was able to acquire a small amount of capital to invest in renting a space and starting up a bar. Joseline would like to buy glasses, drinks, candles, and various supplies to set up her bar. She is also applying for university and is interested in visual arts. Joseline is requesting this loan to invest in setting up her bar. She is thankful for and values the loan offered to her and promises to comply with the payment of her installments according to the timeline established.

Translated from Spanish by Anne Rodriguez, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To invest in setting up her bar

loans.name: Yasmina

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal  “HATUN S. ”; El banco comunal está ubicado en el distrito de Huanchac, provincia de Cusco y departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Yasmina, ella tiene  31 años de edad, es  conviviente y tiene 1 hijo; La socia se dedica a  la venta de artesanía, ella trabaja comprando ala por mayor y vendiendo al por menor en su stand ubicado en la av. Sol.  La socia solicita el préstamo para invertir en la compra de mercadería de tipo artesanal y parte de ellos para sus estudios.

La socia agradece y valora el préstamo otorgado mediante este medio y del mismo modo se compromete en cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
Our associate is a part of the "Hatun S." communal bank, located in the Huanchac district within the Cusco province and department. Yasmina is 31 years old, lives with her husband, and son. She sells arts and crafts and buys them in quantity to resell from her stand, located on the Sol Avenue. She is asking for this loan so that she can invest part of it art merchandise and part toward her studies. She is grateful and values this loan and also the method by which it was obtained. She is committed to repaying it on schedule.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Arts and education

loans.name: Isabel

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal  “HATUN SONCCO ”; El banco comunal está ubicado en el distrito de Huanchac, provincia de Cusco y departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Isabel,  ella tiene  35  años de edad, es casada con 2 hijos; La socia se dedica  la docencia, ella es profesora de profesión en San Sebastián, ella trabaja con el nivel primaria y también  alterna sus actividades con el hogar, La socia desea  mejorar su casa y también para pagar las mensualidades de sus hijos, para lo cual pide el préstamo, que ella irá pagando poco a poco con su sueldo de profesora.  La socia solicita el préstamo para invertir en los estudios de sus hijos.

La socia agradece y valora el préstamo otorgado mediante este medio y del mismo modo se compromete en cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
This member belongs to the Hatun Soncco communal bank. The bank is located in Huanchac District, Cusco Province and Cusco Department. The member is Isabel. She is 35 years old and married, with two children. She is a teacher in San Sebastián; she works at the elementary level and also alternates her activities with responsibilities at home. She wants to improve her house and make her children's monthly school payments, for which she is requesting the loan that she will pay back little by little with her teacher's salary. Isabel is asking for the loan to invest in her children's education. She is grateful for and values the loan granted through this medium, and she promises to make her payments as scheduled.

Translated from Spanish by Danielle Maxson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To invest in children's education

loans.name: Rosa

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal  “HATUN SONCCO ”; El banco comunal está ubicado en el distrito de Huanchac, provincia de Cusco y departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Rosa., ella tiene  53 años de edad, es viuda;  La socia se dedica a trabajar haciendo el reparto de primera necesidad (carne blanca - pollos)  La socia trabaja proveyendo pollos a diferentes empresas, también ella tiene y una tienda abarrotes junto con su madre y ahora necesita el préstamo para implementar la tienda.  La socia solicita el préstamo para invertir en implementar su tienda abarrotes.       
           
La socia agradece y valora el préstamo otorgado mediante este medio y del mismo modo se compromete en cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
The member belongs to the Hatun Soncco communal bank. The bank is located in Huanchac District, Cusco Province and Cusco Department. The member is Rosa. She is a 53-year-old widow. She works delivering staple goods (white meat chicken). The member works providing chickens to different companies. She also has a grocery store together with her mother and now needs the loan to stock her store. The member is asking for the loan to invest in stocking her grocery store. She is grateful for and appreciates the loan granted her through this medium, and she promises to make her payments on schedule.

Translated from Spanish by Danielle Maxson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Stock her grocery store

loans.name: Margarita

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal  “HATUN SONCCO ”; El banco comunal está ubicado en el distrito de Huanchac, provincia de Cusco y departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra.  Margarita; ella tiene 48 años de edad, es  casad y tiene 2 hijos; La socia se dedica a  la venta de comidas, la socia vende huevos con papa y aji por las mañanas en el mercado ella está en la sección de arroz con huevo  y ella también  alterna sus actividades  con el  hogar, La socia desea que sus hijos por los cuales trabaja tanto terminen sus estudios en el instituto y en la universidad para que tengan mejores posibilidades en la vida.   La socia solicita el préstamo para invertir en la compra de ingredientes para su negocio de comidas que irá diversificando.

La socia agradece y valora el préstamo otorgado mediante este medio y del mismo modo se compromete en cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
The member belongs to the Hatun Soncco communal bank. The bank is located in Huanchac District, Cusco Province and Cusco Department. The member is Margarita; she is 48 years old, married, and has 2 children. She works selling foods. She sells eggs with potatoes and garlic in the mornings at the market. She is in the section for rice with eggs, and she alternates her activities with responsibilities at home. The member wants her children, for whom she works so hard, to finish their studies at the institute and the university so they have better options in their lives. She is asking for the loan to invest in buying ingredients for her food business, which she will be diversifying. Margarita is grateful for and appreciates the loan granted her through this medium, and she promises to make her loan payments as scheduled.

Translated from Spanish by Danielle Maxson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of ingredients to diversify her food sales business

loans.name: Misbah

texts.en:
Misbah, the wife of M. N., resides in Kasur, a Pakistani city famous for its sweetmeat and dairy businesses. This 43-year-old caring lady lives with her family and in-laws in a three-room house, taking care of all of their needs.

Misbah's husband, a goldsmith who learned his skill from his father, a famous jeweler of his time, makes jewelry sets, gold bangles and earrings. He started doing this work independently before his marriage in a shop located in the busiest part of the market. Dealing with many customers in a day and fulfilling their requirements, he faces tough competition from other jewelry shops. To compete with them, he keeps current with the new trends and designs of jewelry sets.

Misbah is applying for a loan from Asasah for her husband’s business so that he can diversify his products by adding silver jewelry sets and beautiful gem sets. With the loan he will buy the gems and silver and use them to make new jewelry sets so that lower-income people can also approach him easily. Misbah is hopeful that this investment will help her husband diversify his business and increase his income.

loans.use: To purchase silver and gems for jewelry business

loans.name: Kashifa

texts.en:
Kashifa is the wife of G. M. and resides in Kasur, Pakistan. Kasur city is famous for its sweetmeats. Kashifa is an educated 37-year-old lady. She has completed her education until the 8th standard and couldn’t study further due to the poor financial condition of her family. She got married a few years ago and started taking care of her husband’s family. Her husband and his family respect her a lot for her calm nature and good behavior.  

Her husband has a business renting motorbikes. He gives motorbikes on rent to people and charges them based on the hours they keep the motorbike. His business is going well nowadays. He has two bikes currently but wants to buy another motorbike to increase his income. Therefore, Kashifa has applied for a loan from Asasah for this purpose. With the loan, her husband will buy another motorbike and use it in his business to generate more income. The increased income will help him to improve the living standard of his family.

loans.use: To purchase another motorbike

loans.name: Sourn

texts.en:
Sourn K., 31, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for Pre-Angkorean temples. K. and her husband sell vegetables for an income of USD 3 each per day to help cover the family expenses.  K. is requesting a loan of USD 1200 to purchase more vegetables for resale.

 In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to support the children’s studies.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy more vegetables to resell

loans.name: Morn

texts.en:
Morn S., 39, is married and lives with six of her children in Kampong Chhnang province. She and her husband are farmers who typically make about US$ 1 each day and are supported by two children working in a garment factory. The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year and inflation has also been out of control. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Morn S. included. 

In light of these economic difficulties, she is asking for a loan of US$ 1000 to purchase fertilizer and more farmland to grow rice. She is confident that this loan will allow her to increase her daily income and to better support her family. (Morn S.'s husband is pictured alone.)

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and more farmland

loans.name: Mann

texts.en:
Mann N., 44, is married and lives with her two children in Kampong Chhnang province. She works as a farmer, making approximately US$ 1.50 each day, and her husband works in construction building houses. Her family is also supported by her husband’s US$ 2 income each day. 

Mann N. is asking for a loan of US$ 1000 to  purchase both fertilizer and construction materials. She believes that these purchases will allow her to increase her income and be able to better support her large family.

loans.use: To  purchase both fertilizer and construction materials

loans.name: Kan

texts.en: Kan S., 28, is married and resides with her husband in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for Pre-Angkorean temples. She runs a hair-dressing shop for an income of USD 5 per day. Her husband is a security guard for a private company, earning an income of USD 2 per day.  S. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase a truck to transport dirt to fill in people’s land in her province. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to support the children’s studies.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy a truck to transport dirt

loans.name: Torm

texts.en:
Torm S., 37, is married and lives with her four children in Kampong Chnang province. She works in a grocery store, making approximately US$ 4 each day, and her husband is a garment worker in Malaysia. Her family is also supported by her husband’s US$ 100 income each month, along with the income of one child who works in garment factory in Korea. 

Torm S. is asking for a loan of US$ 800 to expand her grocery inventory. She believes that this purchase will allow her to increase her income and be able to better support her large family.

loans.use: To expand her grocery inventory

loans.name: Shahida

texts.en:
Shahida is the wife of M. I. and they reside in a city called Kasur, in Pakistan. Kasur city is famous for its sweetmeats and dairy businesses. A very vigorous lady, Shahida is involved in the decorative embroidery business. She prepares each dress in  a 15-day time-frame. She gets orders from different boutiques and clothing shops and earns income. She charges them according to the work. For example if she gets an order for a fully embroidered dress then she charges approximately 1500 PKRs for each dress, and if she gets an order for a little embroidery (only on sleeves and on neck) then she charges approximately 400-500 PKRs per dress.  

When she gets big orders from her customers, to complete them in time, her husband helps her with her work. He is also a very talented man who learned to do embroidery from one of the persons living in his community.  

Shahida has applied for a loan from Asasah for her decorative embroidery business. With the loan amount she will buy embroidery items such as beads, colored thread, sketches, needles and cloth in larger quantity. 

The bulk items will help her to fill the larger orders on time with the support of her husband. She is hopeful that she will be able to manage better financial conditions for her house and improve the living standard of her family.

loans.use: Purchase embroidery items in bulk

loans.name: Mao

texts.en: Mao P. is married and lives with four of her children. She is a grocery seller in Kampong Chhnang province, typically making US$ 2 each day, and she is supported by her husband who is a rice worker. This family is also supported by two children’s income of US$ 3 each day. Mao P. would like to take out a loan of US$ 1200 to purchase a motorbike so that she can use it to transport grocery products when she buys them from market.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike

loans.name: Yav

texts.en:
Yav C. is married and resides with her husband in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for Pre-Angkorean temples. She is employed at a local garment factory for an income of USD 3 per day. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver and a farmer, earning an income of USD 3 per day.  C. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase cows to help plow the rice field. 

In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to support the children’s studies.  This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. C.’s husband appears in the photograph because C. was not available.

loans.use: buy cows to help plow the rice field

loans.name: Yuk

texts.en: Yuk R., 32, is married with two young children living at home in Kampong Chnang province. She purchases and sells fish at the local market, typically making US$ 5 each day, and her husband raises pigs, typically making about US$ 2 each day as a pig farmer. Yuk R. would like a loan of US$ 1000 to purchase more pigs to breed and more fish to sell.

loans.use: pigs to raise and fish to sell

loans.name: Leng

texts.en:
Leng S., 42, is married and lives with her three children in Kampong Chnang province. She works in a grocery store, making approximately US$ 3.50 each day, and her husband is a construction worker building houses. Her family is also supported by her husband’s US$ 3 income each day, along with the income of two children who are employed. 

Leng S. is asking for a loan of US$ 1200 to expand her grocery inventory and purchase a plot of farmland to grow rice. She believes that these purchases will allow her to increase her income and be able to better support her large family.

loans.use: To expand her grocery inventory and buy a plot of farmland

loans.name: Sou

texts.en: Sou O., 64, is married and lives with her husband and three children in the Kampong Chhnang province. She has been selling clothes since 2006 and is able to make about US $6 per day. Her husband, pictured here, is too old and stays at home. This family is supported by one child’s income of US $5 each day. Her child sells cosmetic products. Sou O. would like to take out a loan of US $900 for her child to expand her cosmetics store.

loans.use: To expand her cosmetics store

loans.name: Lan

texts.en: Lan C. is married and resides with her husband and three children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for Pre-Angkorean Temples. She is a farmer and grows rice for an income of USD 2 per day. Her husband is a recycler, earning an income of USD 3 per day.  C. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase cows to help plow the rice field. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. C.’s husband appears in the photograph because C. was not available.

loans.use: To buy cows to help plow the rice field

loans.name: Dul

texts.en: Dul K., 63, is a widowed farmer who lives with one of her children in the Kampong Chnang province. She typically makes US $1 each day and would like to increase her profits. She is also supported by one of her children who works as a carpenter with an income of US $2 each day. The weather conditions have been difficult in Cambodia this past year and inflation has also been out of control. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Dul K. included. She is asking for a loan of US $1,000 to make a new investment, selling clothes. (Dul K. is pictured with her son who work as carpenter.)

loans.use: To begin selling clothes

loans.name: Meoun

texts.en: Meoun P. is married and resides with her husband and three children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for Pre-Angkorean Temples. She sells groceries for an income of USD 3 per day. Her husband transports water for the people in the village, earning an income of USD 3 per day.  P. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase more groceries to stock the store. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to stock the store

loans.name: Chuon

texts.en: Chuon K., 59, lives with her younger brother in the Takeo province. She is a farmer who typically makes US $2 each day and is also supported by her brother who is employed at a private company. The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year and inflation has been out of control. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Chuon K. included. In light of these economic difficulties, she is asking for a loan of US $500 to purchase fertilizer. She is confident that this loan will allow her to increase her daily income and to better support her family.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer.

loans.name: Rani's Group

texts.en:
Rani is a wife of M. A. and resides in a city called Kot Radha Kishan in Pakistan. Kot Radha Kishan is a city famous for dairy business.  
She is a vigorous lady who keeps herself busy in her sewing business. She loves this work and tries to makes changes in her sewing. She beautifully crafts new designs on every dress, which attracts more customers towards her. She sews clothes of her neighbors and relatives. She charges between 100-150 PKRs on each dress. The earning amount helps her to manage the financial circle of her house. 
 
Her husband is involved in a wheat-selling business. He buys wheat from the wholesallers and supplies it to other wheat-sellers and earns income on it. He has been in this business for over six years. 

Rani has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband. With the loan amount he will buy the wheat in bulk and fulfill the orders of his customers.  
She is hopeful that this investment will bring the positive change in her husband’s business and he will be able to improve his income.

loans.use: Purchase wheat in bulk to resell

loans.name: Meong

texts.en: Meong K., 51, is married and resides with his wife and three children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. He is a teacher at a public school in the province and earns an income of $ 2.30 (USD) per day. His wife raises poultry at home, earning an income of $1.50 per day.  K. is requesting a loan of $600 to purchase cows to resell. In the future, he would like to use any additional profit to repair his house.  This is his first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: to buy cows to resell

loans.name: Bun

texts.en: Bun P., 48, is married with three children living at home in the Takeo province. She makes and sells rice wine, typically making $4 (USD) each day, and her husband raises pigs. Her husband, Som Sophal, typically makes about $5 each day as a pig farmer. Bun P. would like a loan of $1200 to purchase more pigs to breed and also to purchase feed for the pigs.

loans.use: Raise pigs.

loans.name: Seang

texts.en: Seang R., 32, is married with three young children living at home in the Kampong Cham province. She works in a grocery store, typically making $8 (USD) each day, and her husband is a rice farmer. Her husband, Suong Try, typically makes about $2 each day. Seang R. would like a loan of $1000 to purchase a hand tractor to help him in farm work.

loans.use: To purchase hand tractor.

loans.name: Oah

texts.en: Oah C., 41, is married and resides with her husband and five children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. She sells snacks inside a local school for an income of $ 1.30 (USD) per day. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver, earning an income of $2 per day. C. is requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase a trailer to transport pipes to sell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: to buy a trailer to transport pipes to sell

loans.name: Sin

texts.en: Sin A., 41, is married with two young children living at home in the Takeo province. She raises pigs and sells fish at the local market, typically making $3 (USD) each day, and her husband is a rice farmer. Her husband’s income is $1 each day. Sin A. would like a loan of $600 to reinvest in her fish business.

loans.use: to reinvest in her fish-selling business.

loans.name: Ket

texts.en: Ket T., 54, is married and lives with her three children in the Takeo province. She is a farmer who works for less than $1 (USD) each day, while her husband is a taxi driver making $15 each day. The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year, and inflation has caused food prices to skyrocket. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Ket T. included. In light of these economic difficulties, she is asking for a loan of $800 to replace an old and unreliable mototaxi for her husband.

loans.use: To replace an old and unreliable mototaxi.

loans.name: Him

texts.en: Him S., 31, is married and resides with her husband and a child in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. She sells groceries for an income of $8 (USD) per day. Her husband is a construction worker, earning an income of $2 per day. S. is requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase more construction supplements to expand her husband’s business. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy more construction items for her husband's business

loans.name: Kong

texts.en: Kong S., 48, is married with two children living at home in the Takeo province. She raises pigs and then sells pigs at the local market, typically making $3 (USD) each day, and her husband is a carpenter. Her husband’s income is $5 each day. Kong S. would like a loan of $1000 to purchase carpenter tools for her husband.

loans.use: To purchase carpenter tools.

loans.name: Nget

texts.en: Nget P., 44, is married with five children living at home in the Takeo province. She raises pigs, typically making $2 (USD) each day, and her husband sells firewood. Her husband’s income is $4 each day. Nget P. would like a loan of $650 to purchase more wood to sell.

loans.use: Sell wood.

loans.name: Razia's Group

texts.en:
Razia is a wife of M. A. and resides in a city called Kot Radha Kishan in Pakistan. Kot Radha Kishan is a city famous for dairy business.  
Her husband runs a grocery shop in the nearby market. He has been in this business for over three years. Earlier, his shop was the only shop who dealt with groceries, but now he is facing two more grocery shops in front of him, which can affect his selling. That’s why Razia has applied for a loan from Asasah, so her husband put the groceries in his shop and able to fulfill the demands of his customers on their asking. 

Razia owns a small house of two rooms and is living in it with her family. She is a caring lady and carries out her responsibilities of a housewife effectively. She is hopeful that this investment will bring the positive change to her husband’s business and he will be able to better manage the clientele base.

loans.use: Purchase groceries for grocery shop

loans.name: Cheng

texts.en: Cheng K., 43, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. She produces fishing nets to sell for an income of $2 (USD) per day. Her husband is a farmer, earning an income of $3 per day. K. is requesting a loan of $1200 to purchase a mechanical plow to help plow the rice field. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy a mechanical plow for their rice field

loans.name: Koy

texts.en: Koy T., 34, is married and lives with his two young children in the Takeo province. He raises ducks and work as a farmer, earning $3 each day, while his wife sells chickens making $3 each day. The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year and inflation has caused food prices to skyrocket. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Koy T. included. In light of these economic difficulties, he is asking for a loan of $700 to purchase cows to plow the farmland.

loans.use: To purchase cows to plow the farmland.

loans.name: Dipu

texts.en:
This is 40 year-old Dipu M.. She is married and has 2 children, aged 14 and 16. In 1995, she established her grocery shop business. Working 7 days a week and 10 hours a day, she supoorts her family. She has already received and successfully repaid 7 loans from Patan BPW and used her most recent loan to increase the inventory of her store. In the future, Dipu plans to capitalize more. She thanks you for your support. 

In the Kathmandu Valley, the small grocery stores, called a pasal, is an important part of the local economy. Fresh produce, milk, and staples such as rice, lentils, and flour are purchased daily for cooking in the home. Owners of small grocery stores use Kiva loans to increase their purchasing power and profit margains. By keeping inventory strong and purchasing in larger amounts, owners of these small stores are able to increase profitability.  While a typical pasal might be no more than 100 sq. feet, they are always full of bargaining customers, incoming produce, and shrewd businesswomen. 

This loan was administered by Kiva's local partner MFI, Patan Business and Professional Women. Patan BPW became Kiva's first field partner in Nepal in 2007. Patan BPW operates throughout the Kathmandu Valley, offering microcredit and business training programs to low-income women. In addition to providing economic opportunity to their clients, Patan BPW seeks to empower Nepali women within the home and community. For more information about Patan BPW, visit our partner page and keep an eye out for new loans and borrower updates.

loans.use: increase inventory for store

loans.name: Sorn

texts.en: Sorn Bunthoeurn, 34, is a widow who lives with four children in the Takeo province. Since 1980, she has been making brooms and baskets to sell at the local market, making $3 (USD) of profit a day. Besides this business, she also has a plot of farmland, and now she would like to take out a loan of $900 to purchase fertilizers.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers.

loans.name: Nheib

texts.en: Nheib C., 60, is married with five children living at home in the Takeo province. She grows and sells vegetables, typically making $3 (USD) each day, and her husband runs a mototaxi business. Her husband, Yem Thorn, typically makes about $2 each day. Nheib C. would like a loan of $500 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to operate a mototaxi.

loans.use: to purchase a mototaxi.

texts.en:
This is 28 year-old Sabina S.. She is married and has no children. In 2005, she established  her grocery shop business. Working 7 days a week and 10 hours a day, she supoorts her family. In the Kathmandu Valley, the small grocery stores, called a pasal, is an important part of the local economy.  Fresh produce, milk, and staples such as rice, lentils, and flour are purchased daily for cooking in the home.  Owners of small grocery stores use Kiva loans to increase their purchasing power and profit margains. In addition to providing economic opportunity to their clients, Patan BPW seeks to empower Nepali women within the home and community. loans.name: Azra's Group

texts.en:
Azra is a wife of M. A. and resides in a city called Kot Radha Kishan in Pakistan. Kot Radha Kishan is a city famous for its dairy business. A talented lady, Azra owns & operates a business embroidering and making lace. She crafts beautiful embroidered designs and lace and sells it to different embroidery shops for earning good income.

Her husband is a loader by profession. He uses his horse-cart to deliver different items such as fruits & vegetables and construction supplies through it. He has been in this profession since the last five years. People hired him to deliver their items to the designated places. 

Azra has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband. With the loan amount he will buy a new horse-cart because the old cart has become rough and rotted in different areas, leaving him unable him to load items on it. Azra is hopeful that this investment will help her husband to continue his business well and to provide the better dervice to his customers.

loans.use: Purchase a new horse-cart for loading business

loans.name: Nanda Kumari

texts.en:
This is 65 year-old Nanda kumari S.. She is married and has 3 children aged 45, 35, 26. In 1980, she established her grocery shop business.  Working 7 days a week and 7 hours a day, she supoorts her family. She has already received and successfully repaid 2 loans from Patan BPW and used her most recent to increase inventory of store. In the future, Nanda kumari plans to capitalize more. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: increase inventory of store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy the remaining things necessary for his brother's wedding.

loans.name: Azra's Group

texts.en:
Azra is a wife of A. M. and resides in Kot Radha Kishan in Pakistan. Kot Radha Kishan is a city famous for the dairy business. A very talented and caring lady, Azra owns & operates a sewing business and manages the household responsibilities efficiently. She gets up early, finishes her household chores and then starts sewing clothes for her customers. Her clientele base is her neighbors. She charges between 100-150 PKRs for each dress, which helps her to manage the financial expenses of her family. 

Her husband is involved in selling animals. He buys animals from the animal markets at cheap rates. Then he fattens them up and makes them ready for re-selling. In this way, he generates good income for the family. Above all, he has obtained a good reputation among his customers. They call him when they want to purchase animals because he has a good knowledge of animal breeds and make good deals for them.  

Azra has applied for a loan for her husband’s business. With the loan, he will buy goats and expand his business. Azra is hopeful that this investment will prove beneficial for him and this will help him to grow his business on a large scale by selling to different animal markets & to animal sellers.

loans.use: To purchase goats

loans.name: Radha

texts.en:
This is 56-year-old Radha S..  She is married and has two children who are 30 and 25 years old.  In 1990, she established her grocery shop business.  Working 7 days a week and 8 hours a day, she supports her family.  She has already received and successfully repaid three loans from Patan BPW and used her most recent to increase the store inventory.  In the future, Radha plans to capitalize more.  She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To increase the store inventory

loans.name: Mukhtayaran's Group

texts.en:
Mukhtayaran is the wife of K. M. and resides in a city called Kot Radha Kishan in Pakistan. Kot Radha Kishan is a city famous for its dairy business.  A very caring lady, Mukhtayaran manages the household chores by staying at home. She gets up early, cleans the house and prepares the breakfast for her family. She is also a very supportive lady. She supports her family members in their work. Her in-laws also live with her. She helps her mother-in-law in her embroidery business by making embroidered dresses to complete her orders on time. 

Her husband is involved in the animal selling business. He buys animals, fattens them up, and then resells them to his customers for meat. He has been in this line of work for the last seven years. He specifically deals with goats.  His clientele is made up of butchers because they sell goat meat in their butcher shops. They give him orders because he has a good knowledge of animal breeds and sells them a quality product.

Mukhtayaran has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband. With the loan amount her husband will buy the animals (goats) and fill the orders of his customers.  Mukhtayaran is hopeful that this investment will prove successful for her husband’s business and he will be able to earn a lot on each goat sale.

loans.use: Purchase animals (goats) for reselling

loans.name: Mona

texts.en:
Mona A. is 26 and married with 2 children.  She owns a business venture, selling lavalavas (bottom-half wrap-around prints worn by both men and women).  Mona has 4 years of experience in this business.  Mona needs a loan of WST 1000 to purchase additional fabrics & materials.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 550 talas or US $229 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2010, Mona joined SPBD.    This is her 1st loan with SPBD.   SPBD's loans are Mona's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

About  SPBD 

In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga.  SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.  Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD.  

http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375"

loans.name: Rita

texts.en:
This is 26-year-old Rita C..  She is married and has one child, aged 15 months.  In 2004, she established  her grocery shop business.  Working 7 days a week and 7 hours a day, she supports her family.  She has already received and successfully repaid 3 loans from Patan BPW and used her most recent one to increase the inventory of her store. In the future, Rita plans to capitalize more.  She thanks you for your support. 

In the Kathmandu Valley, small grocery stores called  'pasal' are an important part of the local economy.  Fresh produce, milk, and staples such as rice, lentils, and flour are purchased daily for cooking in the home.  Owners of small grocery stores use Kiva loans to increase their purchasing power and profit margins.  By keeping inventory strong and purchasing in larger amounts, owners of these small stores are able to increase profitability.  While a typical 'pasal' might be no more than 100 sq. feet, they are always full of bargaining customers, incoming produce, and shrewd businesswomen.

 This loan is administered by Kiva's local partner MFI, Patan Business and Professional Women. Patan BPW became Kiva's first field partner in Nepal in 2007.  Patan BPW operates throughout the Kathmandu Valley, offering microcredit and business training programs to low-income women.  In addition to providing economic opportunity to their clients, Patan BPW seeks to empower Nepali women within the home and community. 

 For more information about Patan BPW, visit our partner page and keep an eye out for new loans and borrower updates or join our lending team.

loans.use: increase inventory of store

Danira needs a loan of WST 1900 to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 400 talas or US $167 per week) to pay her children's tuition fees.

texts.en:
This is 24-year-old Hasina R..  She is married but has no children.  In 2007, she established  her grocery shop business.  Working 7 days a week and 7 hours a day, she supports her family.  She has already received and successfully repaid 4 loans from Patan BPW and used her most recent to increase the inventory of her store.  In the future, Hasina plans to capitalize more.  She thanks you for your support. 

In the Kathmandu Valley, the small grocery stores, called a 'pasal', is an important part of the local economy.  Fresh produce, milk, and staples such as rice, lentils, and flour are purchased daily for cooking in the home.  Owners of small grocery stores use Kiva loans to increase their purchasing power and profit margins.  By keeping inventory strong and purchasing in larger amounts, owners of these small stores are able to increase profitability. This loan is administered by Kiva's local partner MFI, Patan Business and Professional Women. Patan BPW became Kiva's first field partner in Nepal in 2007. loans.use: increase store inventory

loans.name: Sabina

texts.en:
This is 28-year-old Sabina R.. She is married and has two children, ages 5 and 7. In 2004, she established her grocery store business. Working seven days a week and eight hours a day, she supoorts her family. She has already received and successfully repaid two loans from Patan BPW. She used her most recent loan to increase the inventory of her store. In the future, Sabina plans to expand the business. She thanks you for your support.

Over 70% of Nepal's economy is agricultural. Typically, Nepali households grow crops on small plots of terraced land. Rice (bhat), lentils (daal), and vegetables (thakari) are the staples of the Nepali diet. With a Kiva loan, BPW's borrowers are able to purchase greater amounts of seed and fertilizer.  With more seeds and fertilizer, a borrower is able to grow cash crops to be sold in the local market. Such crops allow households to move beyond subsistence and provide much-needed cash income throughout the year. 

This loan was administered by Kiva's local partner microfinance institution, Patan Business and Professional Women. Patan BPW became Kiva's first field partner in Nepal in 2007. Patan BPW operates throughout the Kathmandu Valley, offering microcredit and business training programs to low-income women. In addition to providing economic opportunity to their clients, Patan BPW seeks to empower Nepali women within the home and community. For more information about Patan BPW, visit our partner page and keep an eye out for new loans and borrower updates: BPW Partner Page. Join our lending team: BPW Lending Team

loans.use: To increase inventory of store

loans.name: Lalita

texts.en:
This is 31-year-old Lalita D.. She is married and has two children, ages 10 and 5. In 2007, she established her coral carving business. Working seven days a week and seven hours a day, she supports her family. This is her first loan from Patan BPW, which she has used to increase her inventory of coral. In the future, Lalita plans to expand the business. She thanks you for your support.

In Nepal, large supermarkets are rare. Instead, most items can be found in the small, densely packed pasals that line the streets of every city and village. Piled high with utensils, paper goods, and anything else one would need, these stores are your one-stop shop in Nepal. Although usually packed into a space no larger than 100 square feet, these stores carry a sizeable and diverse inventory. With the help of a Kiva loan, pasal owners are able to keep inventory up and their customers happy. Competition is fierce, but with extra capital and a bit of creativity, the opportunity for profit is there.

This loan was administered by Kiva's local partner microfinance institution, Patan Business and Professional Women. Patan BPW became Kiva's first field partner in Nepal in 2007. Patan BPW operates throughout the Kathmandu Valley, offering microcredit and business training programs to low-income women. In addition to providing economic opportunity to their clients, Patan BPW seeks to empower Nepali women within the home and community. For more information about Patan BPW, visit our partner page and keep an eye out for new loans and borrower updates: BPW Partner Page. Join our lending team: BPW Lending Team.

loans.use: To increase coral inventory for carving

loans.name: Sarantsetseg

texts.en: Sarantsetseg B. is 31 years old and lives with her parents and siblings in Hovd province in western Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Sarantsetseg manages a stationery business at a local market in her town. Her father is a taxi driver, and her two younger brothers work for a local construction company. One younger sister helps Sarantsetseg with her business. Her family is very large and very friendly; all family members are working hard to achieve their goals. Sarantsetseg was able to afford a small car with her business revenues and purchased a number of cattle as well. Sarantsetseg is a modest and quiet woman who does not frequently express her thoughts to others. She is requesting a 3,500,000 MNT loan in order to purchase more office stationery for an upcoming academic year.

loans.use: To purchase more office stationery

loans.name: Sunita

texts.en:
This is 37-year-old Sunita M..  She is married and has one child, aged 5.  In 2005, she established her grocery store business.  Working 7 days a week and 7 hours a day, she supports her family.  She has already received and successfully repaid four loans from Patan BPW and used her most recent to increase her store inventory.  In the future, Sunita plans to expand the business.  She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To increase her store inventory

loans.name: Tserenchimed

texts.en: Tserenchimed S. is 40 years old and lives with her husband and daughter in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia in a ger, a traditional nomadic housing tent. Tserenchimed manages a meat retailing business out at Bayanzurh, one of the largest markets in her town, with the help of her husband. She began her business in 2000 and since then, she and her husband have gained much experience and knowledge. Today, their working capital has reached 600,000 MNT. The two have received a lease from Xacbank to purchase a car and eco-fuel, a fuel that is ecologically friendly and its production and use have a minimal impact on the environment. Tserenchimed is a modest woman who wishes to have her own yard and house where the family would live more conveniently than today. Tserenchimed is requesting a 900,000 MNT loan to buy more meat.

loans.use: To buy more meat

loans.name: Nitu

texts.en:
This is 28-year-old Nitu C..  She is married and has one child, aged 6.  In 2003, she established her grocery store business.  Working 7 days a week and 7 hours a day, she supports her family.  She has already received and successfully repaid three loans from Patan BPW and used her most recent to increase the store inventory.  In the future, Nitu plans to send her children to a good school.  She thanks you for your support.

In the Kathmandu Valley, the small grocery store, called a pasal, is an important part of the local economy.  Fresh produce, milk, and staples such as rice, lentils, and flour are purchased daily for cooking in the home.  Owners of small grocery stores use Kiva loans to increase their purchasing power and profit margins.  By keeping inventory strong and purchasing in larger amounts, owners of these small stores are able to increase profitability.
